150599563.review:
This game is an amazing achievement, especially seen by those of us who had already played the first one.
Many times in game trailers we are promised a flow of action, but more times than not those promises are just lies, but not in the case of this game.
The mechanics are introduced in a well paced manner and they can all be mastered easily, allowing for the solutions to the various puzzles to be almost second nature after a while.
Same goes for how immediate one takes action during the majestic escape sequences.

And, by the way, I play with keyboard and mouse, no controller, which could be surprising for many.

All save points are placed in a non-frustrating distance from each other.

The graphics and the sound design, including the made up language, are just perfect, coherent and wonderful to experience.

If one wants to find some problems, the map could have been made more helpful especially in guiding the player through the side quests, which (from an RPG hater) are a pointless addition.

But really, buy this game because it's amazing!

150188250.review:
Oh boy, Ori 2. How much I wish you were better.

I will keep this one short by saying that the only improvements over Ori 1 are things quite literally stolen from games like Hollow Knight.

Otherwise developers have not learned anything from Ori 1.

Trial and error chase sequences? Yup.

Everything is lava endgame? Yup.

Terrible moon logic puzzles? Yup.

Unfulfilling exploration? Yup.

Final boss that completely disregards all of your upgrades, all of your effort of playing a metroidvania, cause your healthbar might as well not exist in it? Yup.

Basically everything I said about Ori 1 in the past is still true here except its so much worse cause the developers had time to learn from their mistakes and they did not.

That makes all of their mistakes just so much more.

This is also a proof that good graphics and music do not make a good game. Your game needs actually a good gameplay. Feels like the devs really wanna make a walking sim or a visual novel rather than a game considering how often then are downright antagonistic towards the idea of the player having any control.

Give your money to Hollow Knight, Bloodstained or even Blasphemous.
If you ok with older games, seek out Cave Story, Iga-made Castlevanias or Super Metroid.

This whole thing has been a horrible disappointment. Started so well, but it just fell down the stairs and kept breaking it's neck.

149675512.review:
More of the same, but better.

Spectacle of colors, beatiful orchestral music and fluid animations. Controlling Ori is fun on it's own because of how responsive and animated it is.
Different locations with distinict vibes and motives, gameplay-wise, some are better (Baurs reach, Luma pools), some not that good (Beginning areas, Midnight Burrows, Silent Woods).
It reuses a lot of cliches from the genre, but they are still well made cliches.

You die a ton, but it has nothing coming close to stuff that Hollow Knight or Celeste have, game actually gives you a lot of help (resources, secrets), which is a biggest flaw to me, because combat and enemies (besides bosses, which are a nice show, but mediocre boss fights) are a chore you rather avoid than fight enjoyably. Which is a shame because there is a lot of upgrades/shard/abillities to experiment with, but in the end you just spam that big arrow and basic slash and facetank everything(even platforming stages!!!) because the game spams health upgrades like it's nothing (hardest difficulty btw)

Story is basic, not overshadowing gameplay, villain is decent enough, ending is fine (And it reveals that Ori is actually Dark Souls: Family Edition). Never felt like it's cheesy or infantile (Maybe one moment, but still - very minor thing).

Lacks more complex secrets, some mistery, and more challange, but overall - if you liked the 1st one, you will like the sequel even more.

Also it's quite impressive how many times you can rearrange the main musical motive and keep it a banger.

[h2] Amazing game 9/10 [/h2]

[h3] Expect to die, and to die alot. It is not a "easy" game but there is an easy mode[/h3]

Game could be 10/10 but there are some parts that I felt is just not as polished when compared to the overall game. 

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is easily one of the best looking games and even after 10 years from now the it will still look great due to the art style and direction. Combined with solid gameplay that builds upon the first game, which is mainly about platforming, Will of the Wisps focuses more on combat with multiple weapons and skills to suit to how you like to play the game. There are some interesting skills and upgrades that can you can find by exploring.

I play with a KB+M and there are some technical issues with rebinding the keys. My main gripes with the game is the story.
I felt that the story in the game could have been so much better but it is lacking some cutscenes or interactions with your "family". [spoiler] Your companions is shown and only seen in cutscenes and you never get to interact with them at all, except for Ku[/spoiler]

If you have a Steam Deck, this is a great game to play on it. You can achieve 60 fps and get decent battery life.

149035988.review:
This game always looked cool to me. I eventually bought it. When I started the game, I was blown away by the graphics and the intro. I was very impressed. Soon after that, though, I got bored with it and frustrated because I couldn't figure out what I was supposed to do. It also hadn't picked up much, since I was only a few hours in. I was bummed I'd spent more than 2 hours playing because I couldn't return it.

A few months later, though, I was bored out of my mind and thought I'd give it a second try. I made myself play it and YouTubed anything I couldn't figure out, and man was it worth it. The game gets better and better as you play, unlocking new abilities and Ori becoming more agile, causing movement to become extremely fun.

This is the first metroidvania I've played. I'm not really a fan of the genre because I like a game to flow perfectly from beginning to end instead of having to backtrack with new abilities, but as far as side-scrollers go, this one has been my favorite. I'll be very impressed if any other side-scroller can top this. This game is very special to me.

148851378.review:
If you haven't played Blind Forest I'd recommend playing through it first though it isn't necessary to enjoy this.

This game has the most satisfying movement system I've ever used and the combat is much more interesting than in Blind Forest.

I played on hard and the only real complaint I have is the first boss is ridiculous on hard (not sure on other difficulties my first playthrough was normal difficulty on switch a while ago) it 2 hits you, and has a very small window to attack without getting absolutely destroyed, and if you don't keep the pressure on the boss it will corner you and crush you, body and soul, so expect to die many times, which sucks because every time you do die you have to repeat a 10-20sec running away section before the fight begins, which gets kinda annoying after a couple of deaths, after you get past the first boss nothing feels unfair and as you unlock more and more movement options it gets really satisfying just getting from point A to point B.

The bosses are fun and can be a little overwhelming at first but learn their tells and find openings to attack and you'll get through without too much trouble, though you can make them pretty unforgiving if you have a bunch of charms that increase enemy damage dealt and your damage received, as well as one charm that increases both enemy health and damage dealt by 70% which does apply to bosses, most of those charms I keep on for general gameplay to boost my damage and increase rewards and I don't bother changing them for a good 10-20 attempts because I'm stubborn, and as far as I'm aware bosses don't drop directly anything they give you scripted rewards so I'm pretty sure the only thing the +70% charm does during a boss fight is make the fight harder.

One other minor gripe is the game doesn't capture the mouse to the window/monitor so if you have multiple monitors you will click out and minimize the game, it does auto pause on loss of focus so it's not a big deal but it can be easy to lose track of your mouse during a boss fight or escape sequence which can pull you out the groove, obviously this isn't an issue if you use a controller.

148663048.review:
Give this a miss. I'd say the game is creatively bankrupt, and offers almost no technical improvements over the first game. This is little more than a 'cynical' cash-grab. The only thing I can say was done well is the eye candy. The game has about 15 hours' worth of gameplay in it.

They care so little about the game, they didn't even fix some of the noticeable problems with the first game: 
 - the map still doesn't correctly show all areas that have been explored (and sometimes barely shows walls, so you think you didn't fully explore an area when you did). 
 - The controls are incredibly loose and you're fighting against them to get the character to do what you want at times. (Your character sticks to the wall like a magnet.)
 - The gameplay is incredibly shallow.
 - The game may as well be linear. It's really not a metroidvania. You can go anywhere at any time, you just *may* miss some secrets the first time around. Realistically, I could get all secrets with the equipment I had by about 5 hours in. There's not much sense of mystery, like 'How do I access this area? Will I get some upgrade later?'. Mostly it's straightforward.

Additionally,
 - The game is incredibly easy (apart from the occasional boss battle, which are just frustrating really.)
 - So many platforms gesticulate, flop and smush around like they're made of gelatin-- even things that are supposed to be hard rocks or wood. I think the devs were very impressed with themselves for making this interesting visual effect, and so they spammed it everywhere. Another sign the devs don't care about the game, and just see it as a visual art project.
 - The gameplay is frequently interrupted by the most predictable, repetitive cutscenes-- they copied the setpieces from the first game too, so it's not even novel the first time you hide behind barriers to avoid a big owl in the background. For some reason, you can skip some of these cutscenes but not others.
 - They tried to ripoff Hollow Knight's badge system, and they failed almost completely. 
 - The story is terrible and so nonsensical at times that it would be funny if it weren't embarrassing. Things happen because they thought 'this is the kind of story beat that should happen at a time like this', with no connection to the worldbuilding or narrative. Big frog gets possessed by shadow creature (without any warning or narrative setup) because that's just the kind of thing that should happen in a game like this. And of course it finishes with a boss battle, after which he overcomes the possession and then dies. It's extremely predictable and generic, and it doesn't even fit in with the narrative. The visual of the shadow creature carrying the big toad is so absurd-- there's no reason the shadow creature would try to attack you with this huge, cumbersome toad. It's an extremely ineffective way to attack the player; it's clearly done because they devs have no understanding of narrative or art, even at a layman commonsense level, and they just thought that's the kind of thing which happens in a story like this. 

With the story being so nonsensical, yet predictable and generic, and no improvements made to the noticeable flaws of the first game in regards to gameplay, it's hard to see this as anything but a visual arts project for the dev team.

If you haven't played Hollow Knight yet, play that.

148657781.review: Beautiful graphics and soundtracks. more game play mechanics compared to the first one. Definitely a must play.

148646570.review:
"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is a masterpiece in the world of platformed games. Building upon the success of its predecessor, "Ori and the Blind Forest," this sequel takes players on an enchanting and emotionally charged journey through a beautifully hand-drawn world.

The game excels in several aspects. Firstly, its visuals are simply breathtaking. The game's stunning art style and attention to detail create a magical atmosphere that draws players in. The lush forests, intricate caverns, and diverse biomes are a testament to the artistry of the developers at Moon Studios.

But it's not just the aesthetics that shine; the gameplay is equally exceptional. "Will of the Wisps" refines the platforming mechanics of the first game, providing a smooth and enjoyable experience. The addition of new abilities and upgrades keeps the gameplay fresh and engaging. The combat has also been enhanced, offering more variety in how you approach and defeat enemies.

One of the most memorable aspects of this game is its storytelling. The narrative is emotionally charged, and the characters are endearing. Ori's journey is a heartwarming and often heart-wrenching one, as you navigate through themes of friendship, sacrifice, and the power of hope.

The soundtrack, composed by Gareth Coker, is a work of art on its own. It complements the game's emotional depth and artistic beauty, immersing players further into the world of Nibel.

While "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is a near-perfect gaming experience, it's not without its challenges. Some may find the difficulty spikes to be a bit steep, and there are occasional bugs or performance issues that can detract from the experience. However, these minor flaws are easily forgiven when weighed against the game's many strengths.

In summary, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is a must-play title for fans of platforms, storytelling, and beautiful art. It's a captivating and emotional journey that will leave a lasting impression, and it solidifies its place as one of the standout games of its genre.

It's impossible to capture this game in a brief review. It's a metroidvania game that delivers everything you'd expect and more, including ideal difficulty puzzle and platforming sequences. The visuals, music, solid mechanics, and so much more! I strongly recommend playing this game without any spoilers. 148624339.review:
Coming straight from Ori 1 and expecting staple things to remain mechanically same, and being greeted with changes to things that weren't broken into a sidegrade at best, or a downgrade in a few cases. (specifically light burst throw). 

It was also rather overwhelming and even immersion breaking with how many things were going on at the same time, being given sidequests etc., it felt like so much compared to the perfected, more streamlined but not restrictive progress the first game.

However, graphically the game is a straight upgrade, Ori controls the exact same, the most important and staple movements are present and the gameplay feels smooth and very satisfying when mastered.

I can't not mention the difficulty spike, the game almost expecting you to have played the first game or get "punished" ( - learn through trial and error), especially if you hop straight into hard difficulty. Difficulty coming from not the enemies this time, as health and resource management in this game is a lot more lenient than before, as enemies now drop health and energy shards, but when it comes to bosses, they're pretty spongy. They take a while sometimes and you've pretty much mastered the whole bossfight by the time you're done, and it feels nice? I don't tend to enjoy these kinds of victories but it really feels nice against things that don't really use BS strategies to harm you (except in the finale :))
*Note, I only played it on Hard, I don't know if enemies drop health on normal

I recommend you play with a controller, as it feels natural for a 2d platformer. If you have prior controller experience, you really should try the Ori duology, even if you aren't that big on platformers. (Blind forest comes before Will of the Wisps)
It's a journey and experience that I last remember experiencing as a kid, on the ps2. If you found this one, congrats! You found gold in the rough, [i]even if it's far from a small title.[/i]

148517915.review:
The game is very enjoyable, smooth movements, the art, the graphics everything was enjoyable. The game is also way bigger than the first one, they have implemented NPCs, quests and skill building. You can collect equippable upgrades, use different weapons/fighting styles now. 

Even if what i'm about to say is negative, i still highly recommend the game because the negative comments are only MY OWN experience, and a lot of people (who enjoys a little more strategy and puzzling) wouldn't agree with me. I play for the story and relaxation.)

With all the new stuff to the game compared to the old Ori (which was a very simple platform game), this game was a little  too overwhelming. There were just too many abilities to keep track on. Some abilities were only used in certain regions and never outside of it which was unnecessary. The Burrow ability was super wonky, you could only burrow when the blue indicator showed up and because it shared the same button (i use controller) as Dash, sometimes when you wanted to burrow, you'd dash instead and lose your momentum, it was insanely frustrating. 
There were also too many weapons and some parts in the game required a certain weapon to proceed (like hitting a wall) was very annoying because you'd have to change them back and forth very often.

I still loved and enjoyed the game very much, however i dont think i will be able to finish it because it's just too much and i am starting to lose interest in it.

147934060.review: An amazing sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest, everything in here incorporates most of the features in the prequel and on top of that included additional features that were both unique and ingenious. The OST, gameplay, and storyline were all top notch and if not better than the sequel. What stands out between Ori and the Will of the Wisps and Ori and the Blind Forest would have to be the combat system, as in this sequel, it follows through with a rather dynamic boss battle system to progress which I think brings a lot of life to the gameplay. Sure, the order of progression might be confusing to most people, but I think the essence of having free will to make the choices yourself bring out a lot of adventuring as you are exploring the map. But besides that, one area of concern in Ori and the Will of the Wisps would be that it isn't low-end friendly as compared to Ori and the Blind Forest, the graphics can sometimes be rather demanding, the gameplay and cinematics may become choppy, but that rarely disrupts the smooth flowing of the gameplay. Other than that, this game is high recommended 11/10.

147784951.review:
I keep going back and forth whether this game is a quintessential gaming masterpiece, or just a worthy sequel to one. Either way it's phenomenal and definitely worth buying.

Playing "Ori and the Blind Forest" first is not technically required, but I do recommend playing it first. The worst part about this game is that it does rehash some parts of the original, but also has so many mechanical and design improvements (many of which are not-so-subtly borrowed from Hollow Knight) that it sorta nullifies the gameplay of the original. It also feels a little shorter, but that might be because for me the muscle memory of Blind Forest carried me through about 2/3 of the games challenges.

Other than that there's nothing bad to say. The graphics are incredible. The platforming is satisfyingly technical yet feels buttery smooth. The new world has a lovable cast of characters in diverse biomes. The plot takes a bit to get going but brings it home with some very emotional resolutions. The soundtrack is beautiful (although I'm pretty sure the villain theme is just Seven Nation Army) Across the board the level of polish and care is immaculate.

[quote=TalePlay][i] Check our [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/38352719/] Curator Page [/url] for short reviews. If you wish to get more gaming listings, news and reviews check our [url=https://www.youtube.com/@tale_play] Youtube [/url] channel as we release videos there often.[/i][/quote] 
 
[h2]In-depth[/h2] 
[h3] ⚔️ Gameplay & Exploration: [/h3]  
  
Puzzle platformer is still the key of the game. Despite having a larger map to explore, this time around, with the additional abilities and tricks you can pull off, it seems a lot faster to get from an area to another.

The game introduces new abilities while requiring players to reactivate and relearn old ones. Ori is more capable this time around when it comes to its arsenal, but still fragile in combat. The game features excellent traversal and progression mechanics, with periodic main narrative follow-throughs necessary for full completion. 

Boss fights are challenging, and chase sequences are less frustrating than the first game.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2lD_mAKechc&t=2s
 
[h3] 😄 Fun: [/h3]

Like the previous game, I've enjoyed this game a lot and it was nice to return to this world.
 
[h3] 🏞 Visuals & Presentation: [/h3]  
  
The game boasts gorgeous visuals with notable improvements, featuring intricate details in the world. Although the impact may not be as strong due to the fact that it's not too far from the original and that sense of newness is kinda of gone. Still,  it remains one of the most stylistically impressive games.

Like before, yet even more improved, there are different map sections exhibit diverse biomes, ranging from lush forests to candy-like landscapes, deserts, frozen areas, and dark caves. 

Like before, there is a map like an ant colony. It looks weird but fits well within the game's context and adds to its overall appeal.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3046285181
 
[h3] 🔊 Sound & Voice-Acting: [/h3]  
 
The music this time around is a lot softer, and despite featuring an incredible soundtrack, I honestly enjoyed the end song of the first game more. Nevertheless, there's quality in all aspects, from the voice acting performed by characters that can't be understood, to the beautifully crafted sound effects.
  
[h3] 📖 Story & Writing: [/h3]  

Ori and the Will of the Wisps takes Ori to a different location: a mysterious island, after Ori and Ku, his little owl friend, get pulled in by a strong storm while flying together and are separated as they both fall on this new world. You continue to play as Ori, the mysterious and cute spirit creature capable of using its energy to solve puzzles, fight enemies, and overcome obstacles.

Your journey starts as you explore this vast new world. Although the map is three times bigger than the prequel, the sequel does a great job of making you feel as if the map isn't so vast, thanks to the fact that you now have many more abilities to enhance traversal, exploration, and movement, making the experience more intense, rapid, and interesting.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=3046282624
 
[h3] 🧵 Length & Difficulty: [/h3]  
  
The game can take some time to beat and complete, especially if you plan to have multiple runs. It's fairly difficult when it comes to some areas or boss fights, but if you play the game right from the get-go in highest difficulty you'll realize that the most challenging part is the boss fights.

[h3] ⭕️Verdict: [/h3]  
Although there have been great improvements made in combat, graphics, and the story, there was something about the original that I enjoyed more. Maybe it's the element of newness, or the fact that the music resonated with me differently, but overall, I think that if you've played and enjoyed the first game, you'll enjoy the sequel just as much. It's a worthy package that should be played one after the other as it holds a dear spot in my heart.

147602939.review:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is what a true sequel is meant to be. It takes everything its predecessor fell short in and improved upon immensely. Some of the major pros below:

The combat system has been flushed out and is actually really comprehensive and dynamic. Due to the refined combat system, fighting enemies and bosses is much more enjoyable rather than just mashing the same button. The bosses and enemies are much more diverse and include a challenging but fair skill level to beat. 

The movement mechanics have drastically improved despite Blind Forest already being so fluid. The main difference is that you get more useful and comprehensive movement techs earlier in the game rather than going through half the game and finally getting a double jump like in its predecessor. A good metroidvania excels in movement and getting the best movement tech early in the game will keep the player motivated and enjoying rather than struggling and bored. 

The story surprised me on how elaborate it was and I think it was a perfect continuation from the previous title. The characters were so charming and unique. Many side quests along side the main missions and the map flushed out everything in a readable manner. 

The score is exceptional and I did not think it was possible to create better tracks than Blind Forest. I truly felt immersed in many of the sequences and the music was perfectly pitched in the background. Alongside the music was the amazing art direction. Blind Forest already excelled in this department but it was taken to the next level in this game. 

Among the many compelling attributes that Ori and the Will of the Wisps inherits, it's the little things that count. And I won't mention exactly what these are but as you play the game, the small touches really showcase the passion and drive the team had when developing this game. A level of quality and attention to detail that you don't see in modern titles. 

I think Moon Studios absolutely knocked it out of the park and I am looking forward to what they can bring in the future. For the $7.49 sale price, this game is an absolutely gem.

147109892.review:
It's like 1:50 AM, I don't got the brain to write a pretty, in-depth review so take my "I just finished the game and I have to take an adderall for this monster headache" thoughts.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is ABSOLUTELY gorgeous, in like, every sense of the word. Graphically and artistically. There's VERY little to take you out of your immersion, other than Shriek's model clipping through itself in one (1) cutscene. The whole world is beautiful (Luma Pools is actually heaven I think) and the music... GOD the music.

I turned that sh*t up to 11 and blasted my eardrums out and y'know what? Worth it, every time. The frosty music for Baur's Reach actually had me crying when I was running through it trying to get 100% completion.

Some of the chase sequences had a few moments where I was like "Man, I don't know where I'm GOING" and it got me killed more times than lack of skill did - so that's annoying. However, it's a minor gripe.

Something Ori and the Will of the Wisps has over its predecessor (Ori and the Blind Forest) is the combat. I have nothing against the combat in the original game, but it's simply better in the sequel. You have more options to fit your fighting style (melee, ranged, mage, whatever), it feels smoother, and when combined with the new movement abilities, it gives you nice, clean gameplay.

Every boss was FANTASTIC with only one giving me trouble and a headache so bad I was forced to take a break. [spoiler]Mora was mostly fine, my biggest gripe being with her tells. 
When she summons spiderlings, she screeches. When she tries to melee you, she screeches. When she spits acid at you, she screeches. See the problem? It plays the same sound for every attack. That doesn't help me figure out what she's doing ahead of time, so I took a lot of cheap hits.
I died a lot during her last phase where she makes the arena dark, but that's due to my own idiocy in not realizing I could just... turn on my light spell and simply not take damage.[/spoiler]

Overall, I enjoyed the HELL out of Ori and the Will of the Wisps - more than it's predecessor? I don't know! It's been so long since I've played it, I can't compare them that well. (if i replay it in the future i'll let y'all know) Even if I do replay and find WotW worse, it will still have been a good, worthwhile experience.

Lastly, the only reason I'm not talking about the story is because... it's Ori. Y'all know the story baller as f*ck, I don't gotta tell you. (I cried by the way, if that gives you an idea.)

147022610.review:
This is without doubt my favorite game. I finished it multiple times, and I get as much pleasure each time as the first. 
It is incredibly beautiful, enchanting, adorable and the graphics are outstanding. The music is honestly one of the best soundtrack I've ever experienced. I often listen to it when I don't play, the composer can be proud. 
The story is beautiful and makes me cry each time. Very touching and well told. 
One of my favorite part of the game is simply how amazing it is to move in this game. It is so quick, reactive and satisfying. Especially as you unlock the last abilities, you really feel like a god moving around the platforms. It's really outstanding. 
It makes it even hard to play other games as they all seem too slow and sluggish compared to Ori. 
I would like to add that the game really improved from the first one. The combat is better, there is much more life and I like the quests. It feels like an amazing expansion to the universe of Ori and the Blind Forest and I am dreaming of a third one.. 
Just... awesome :)

146859419.review:
Excellent game. Even better OST than in the original. Gareth Coker is a genius, I saw him at the Games Music Festival in London. He is so dedicated to composing game music and so dedicated on making it fit every moment of the game, that he played it for over 1000 hours during his 4 years of working on the score. The 4K HDR looks insanely good and the world is beautiful. I can't stop staring at the main menu. Ori's responsiveness is even better than in an original game and is incredibly smooth. This game hits emotionally hard again. We finally have more flexibility when it comes to saving. The ending is good, bittersweet and I like that the cycle is completed and it is a perfect closure to both games. I could praise this game for hours. This and Hollow Knight are the best that the metroidvania genre has ever had to offer.

Everyone is praising this game and for a good reason, so I will focus on what could have been better about this 9.5/10 game:
-I was a little disappointed with how little time we were able to play as Ku. Watching the trailers, I assumed that more focus would be given to her in both story and gameplay. I was hoping for some mystery about the owls and that the plot would go a bit in that direction.
-The main "antagonist" is not as good as in the first game. In terms of how we fear her and in terms of her origin story, which is just sad and that's it.
-Platform challenges and escape sequences seem less challenging, and that is what I enjoyed in the first game. I loved the satisfaction of beating the Ginso Tree sequence in the original. Dying 30 times to that epic music was amazing. On the other hand, we get Spirit Trials as a challenge.
-I liked the addition of the NPCs, and the Mokis are really cute, but these RPG elements decreased my immersion. Don't get me wrong, there was nothing wrong with the way they were executed, but you should be in a dying land, desperately looking for a way to save it, not being distracted by a friendly chat, doing quests and building. I don't want to spoil, but compared to the original game, the land's situation should be even more dire.
- I liked the boss fights, but Hollow Knight does it better, and I think the game should focus on what it does best, which is chase/escape sequences and platform challenges that have been shortened and made easier in this game. However, HK doesn't have such responsive movement, so it's still enjoyable and refreshing to have those fights from time to time, especially fight with Mora the Spider (and that music change in the middle was crazy!).

Ori and the Blind Forest was great and unique, but this sequel really completed what made the first one so awesome. Some mechanics feel weird, which is probably where most of the difficulty comes from. However, at the same time, they are super creative and unconventional. In terms of how this relates to other metroidvanias, it seemingly takes inspiration from a lot of the ones I played up until this point, but does it so well that it is hard to be upset about it. The visuals are perfect and the OST is a really awesome twist on the first game's sound track, as well as new tunes that make the journey feel much darker but still emotional. Gotta address the elephant in the room for differences between this and the first game [spoiler] Combat is refined and now there's bosses and boss chases and they are awesome, they did not slack here whatsoever [/spoiler]. I kind of felt weird about all the different movement options towards the end of the game, because I often misinputted due to the time pressure, and forgetting that certain movements are mapped rather than LB or RB on the controller. Exploring in this game is great, and there's virtually no punishment for going the wrong way [spoiler] especially if you have the instant teleport item [/spoiler]. 

This is very close to a perfect game in my mind, though some may find it surprisingly challenging. Awesome effort from the development team!

146676313.review:
Feel free, like a leaf in the wind.

Another masterpiece from Moon.
Another gem, another diamond.

Same tight and intuitive gameplay, beautiful soundtrack, amazing graphics and art style as before.
More of the same awsomeness in a new adventure, could've we asked for more?

We can see that a lot has been influenced by and borrowed from Hollow Knight in this one, from the Spirit Edge similar to the Nail and the Shards just like the Charms. These aren't bad additions, it does add more flexibility in a build you could make with the Charms and where as the Nail in Hollow Knight allows you to bounce off of enemies by attacking down, in Ori, a hit resets your jump count so if you're hitting and jumping right, you can keep being airborn, which feels -so -good.

You'll find most of the shards exploring or from some NPCs and this is where you'll get to select your double jump, your wall grab as well as other buffs and other helpful benefits. You unlock more shard slots the more you go.  

The main abilities are now in a wheel that you can access with LT, stopping time, allowing you to select your skills and put them in your shortcuts (X,Y,B). This is where your main attack, Spirit Edge, is as well as Recover for life recovery, fire orbs, a spear and such.

It feels a little too much compared to the simple and effective way the first game was built around, unlocking your abilities felt more natural without having to select them, but it's well done still, I got used to it without much issues, everything flowed well because the game got great design in overall. 

Differently from the first game where you had a skill tree where you would spend the Spirit Light you're collecting, all the shards and abilities can be upgraded with Spirit Light at certain NPCs now.

Talking about NPCs, they now also give some side quests and we got a Trade Quest like in A Link's Awakening. The throwback.

So, one more time, one of the best Metroidvania.
A third game would be more than appreciated because there's nothing like it.

146507791.review:
[h1] !!MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS (I'll make sure to hide the spoiler parts) [/h1]

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is just another masterpiece. Just like Ori and the Blind Forest (which you should play, if you didn't already do it), get ready to be amazed by the beautiful soundtracks and places and be prepared for another emotional story.

The gameplay is just as amazing as in the first game, except you have more abilities (which you can upgrade AND you can use more than one), the open world concept feels more open as you can explore every place multiple times, the saving system changed into an autosave method (which can work in your favor a lot of times) and you get to meet lots of NPC's with all sorts of cute tasks. ([spoiler] except one task that will give you a big punch in the heart. You'll see what I'm talking about [/spoiler]). The visuals are just breathtaking and the music fits beautifully. You'll get through all sorts of emotions, from anger to sadness, from depressed to being incredibly joyful. 

The combat system is really changed. Now we have interesting bosses ([spoiler] the last one shouldn't be a boss. Remember that punch in the heart? Double it. Actually, triple it [/spoiler]) with amazing moves and abilities. Each weapon is required in certain places and the amazing thing is that you can change your weapon any time you want. Even when you're mid battle! There are lots of upgrades for your weapons and you can even get new ones. Speaking of upgrades, you can equip lots of them with the help of shards that you won't miss. 

The controls are as amazing as ever. Everything feels so smooth, especially when you progress through the game and you get some more abilities. Basically, you take everything good from Ori and the Blind Forest and you bring new and better elements to it. 

The visuals are just out of this world. I know that it's been said numerous times, but I just can't help it. Every place (even the not so friendly ones) seems like it's from some amazing fairytale or picture. The lighting system combined with amazing details gives life to the world of Niwen. Of course, we can't forget about the soundtrack that really brings every place to life. Gareth Coker is this amazing God that can create soul piercing soundtracks for the Ori franchise. Every piece is so intense that it makes everything so real. The original theme from the first game is wonderfully "sneaked" into the new soundtracks that it kinda gives a feeling of nostalgia. 

Now, the ending (more like a rant) [h2] MAY CONTAIN SPOILERS! Everything will be covered and I'll post a spoiler free conclusion [/h2]
The ending finished me. I've never been this devastated after a game since the first Ori game (even then, it wasn't THIS bad). [spoiler] In my opinion, this game has two endings. The soul wrenching, heart stomping, stomach punching one and the other that doesn't really feel like an end (more like a sequel posibility). Over the course of the game you'll find an even sadder owl story. The first ending involves her and I'm really not happy with it. Call me a brat, but I enjoy happy endings, especially for characters like this poor owl. This game talks about forgiveness and redemption, but this is the part where it fails. After you have to FIGHT with this character, you have to see the saddest cinematic in the whole world and then you have to accept the fact that nothing can be done. And don't get me started with the fact that nobody remembers her, nobody goes to visit her, she doesn't even appear in the credits (in the little arts between credits). It feels like nobody cared about her, EVER, and that's just so heartbreaking. At the end of the game I didn't even know how to feel. Sad or angry for this seemingly rushed ending. You can't get us invested in this sad story and expect us to have the will to fight her. I hope that there'll be a definitive edition that will give her a happy ending. Or at least a sequel with something related to this story. [/spoiler]. It's an Ori game, so you should expect to be emotionally drained, but I feel that everything was much more emotional and sadder.

So yes, I really REALLY recommend Ori and the Will of the Wisps. I recommend the whole Ori franchise. This game isn't called a masterpiece for nothing. You'll be welcomed into amazing worlds that are brought to life with the help of stunning visuals, cute and amazing characters, emotional stories and out of this world music. You'll find yourself taking screenshots from minute to minute (I think I have 500 of them) and you'll love every nook and cranny of the world that beautifully appears before your eyes.

Ori WotW is the perfect continuation of Ori BF. It does the same as its predecessor but better, adding new moves, the shards, a wheel of abilities, characters, shrines, secondary missions and new combat mechanics among others. It is also "easier" than BF, automatic save points everywhere, warping from everywhere and less difficult chase parts. The addition of bosses is also interesting. Finally, the high number of secrets and hidden treasures makes it longer. Overall, a metroidvania with a particular style, closer to other titles like hollow knight, more focused on combat than BF, but still keeping that made Ori BF a fantastic game. If we compare them I'd say:
- BF does better in story, characters, music, environment and difficulty
- WoW does better in length, secondary quests, combat mechanics, exploration and secrets

If you liked OBF you will probably like this, if you didn't you won't like this.

The platforming mechanics is nearly identical to the first game with a couple additional move sets to really enhance Ori's abilities. You get the bash mechanic pretty quick, which is nice, cause that might be ONE OF THE GREATEST GAMING MECHANICS EVER INTRODUCED up there with revert in tony hawk. 

You get a nice selection of shards that enhance your ability. You can specialize them to your play style. I went for pure platforming often opting to use grapple and bash as a primary attack option, shit was so fun. 

The combat system is really robust now, almost overwhelming, being that I felt like I could only really sink my teeth into a couple of the weapons where most of them, I just scratched the surface with them. But honestly, it's still great that there is so many options to stylize your combat. 

Story is beautiful, much like the last. Graphics were fucking gorgeous. 

The one thing I can't really forgive is rip-off Cornifer (Hollow Knight map guy),
I don't even remember the map guys name, not charismatic, not comforting, just kind of weird and forgettable.

I wish they had one of the Mokis be the cartographer or.. something different, I dunno, it just felt too much like a rip-off.  

9/10

145627967.review:
I don't remember much of the first game, besides that I really liked it. I got to this one pretty late, but I enjoyed it as well. The biggest strength is the movement; it feels amazing flying around the map with multiple jumps, boosts off enemies and their projectiles. You need to unlock a few abilities, takes maybe 90-120 minutes before the game really opens up and becomes a lot more enjoyable IMO. Once it did I was all in, up until that point I was a bit bored. 

The combat is easily one of the weakest parts of the game. If you've played games like [i]Hollow Knight[/i] and [i]Blasphemous 2[/i] to name a few examples, you're gonna be pretty let down by this aspect of the game. I honestly enjoy the escape sequences from the original Ori more than any of the boss fights here which are all super easy. The combat is so strange because everything is easy, but at the same time, making the enemies more challenging wouldn't necessary make it better because the attacks you have kinda just suck and feel underwhelming. I also found it really annoying that you can only have 3 abilities equipped at once; most games like this would typically allow you to use all your abilities via different button inputs, or a better control scheme so that felt pretty bad.

Similar to the original, the game is beautiful, and the music is amazing. It's certainly a game that is more accessible to newer Metroidvania players, and will be more enjoyable if you haven't played some of these other titles that have incredible combat. Regardless, it's still a fun experience and offers music and visuals that are thoroughly enjoyable. Not my favorite, but a good game that I'd recommend.

[b]Recommended[/b]

[i]If you found my review helpful, please consider following my [url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/44234346/]Steam Curator page[/url] where you can see more thoughts and recommendations[/i]

145553410.review:
In a world where colors dance and dreams unfurl,
There lies a tale, beautifully twisted and twirled,
Ori and the Blind Forest, a vision to behold,
A game of light, of stories richly told.

The palette breathes life, a cascade of hues,
From ethereal blues to sunset's warm muse,
Each shade plays a part, every beam, every ray,
Crafting an atmosphere that sweeps us away.

Mechanics not just tools, but a dance of the sprites,
Synchronizing seamlessly with the moon's gentle lights,
With each leap and bound, the forest comes alive,
A testament to gaming, where art and action thrive.

The narrative is a beacon, its message shines bright,
Keep the fire within, never surrender the light,
In a world that may sometimes seem dark and askew,
It teaches us goodness, to ourselves be true.

An ode to nature, to its power and grace,
A reminder to cherish, protect, and embrace,
The trees, the rivers, the air that we breathe,
Respect for the wild, a promise to bequeath.

Ori stands as a testament, a beacon so clear,
That in gaming, beauty and meaning cohere,
In this forest, both blind yet profoundly wise,
Lies a journey of heart, a soulful surprise.

145544255.review:
Chill vibes, stunning graphics, and smooth controls!

It feels amazing to travel around the world, even though I unlocked fast travel, I still find myself doing it manually because it feels so good to string movement together: jump, dash, double jump, grapple, parry...

Combat was fun too, maybe a bit too easy. I wish it was more challenging. The only challenging part of the game is the platforming/puzzles, which are both great! It feels satisfying to figure it out, and the game doesn't overuse the same mechanic/puzzle a lot, keeping you engaged and not bored.

Overall, I highly recommend the game. Even though it's a new separate story in a new place, I recommend playing the first one first to get a better understanding of the world and the characters.

145381506.review:
This game is a masterpiece. I mean, no joke. The combination of the music, the visuals, the emotional storytelling, and the fun and amazing combat and platforming is just beyond outstanding. All the great things from its predecessor return, but better in all aspects, plus epic boss fights that will give a great challenge to players. This is a wonderful example of a sequel that, without exaggeration, improves upon its predecessor in every way. The controls are tighter, the worlds are more fun than ever to navigate, and the worlds are more vivid than ever. Will of the Wisps is, for sure, one of the best Metroidvania and 2D platformers ever made.

It is also clear that much more time was put into the story of the game, which has a certain knack for tugging on the heart strings more than once, though the gameplay is more than enough to justify playing this game if you don't care about the story as much. Right now, there are some technical and performance issues that may disturb the experience but are fixable over time, which I really don't bother with and deny my not giving it 5 stars. It's a must-play. And believe me, tears will be shed. Kudos to Moon Studios for showing us all over again how to blur the line between a simple "game" and "art".

145356486.review:
Ori and the will of the wisps es, sin duda alguna, una gran obra. Con un impresionante y único apartado gráfico extremadamente cómodo a la vista y muy bello, en muchas ocasiones tuve que detenerme a apreciar el paisaje a detalle, y varias veces decidí guardar una foto, así de bueno es el arte. La música hecha por orquesta es una maravilla, hecha a la medida para resaltar cada zona, como en el bosque silencioso, la música hace una perfecta labor contándonos los triste y desolada que es la zona, acompañada por una paleta de colores que hacer precisamente eso. Dando como resultado zonas interesantes a la vista y la escucha. La música sabe ser tensa y épica cuando se necesita, los bossfights y las persecuciones son entretenidos por esto, y por el siguiente aspecto a recalcar, el gameplay: muchos dicen que es muy parecido al de hollow knight, y es cierto, si. Pero presenta una gran mejora frente al gameplay del primer juego. Siendo mucho más amplio y adaptable al jugador y situación en la que te encuentres. Y lo mejor de todo: La historia y sus personajes. El mundo de Ori and the will of the wisps está poblado por npcs que le dan vida a la aventura, cada uno con cierta personalidad que los hace memorables, algunos más que otros. otros no tanto. Pero memorables sin duda. La historia lleva buen ritmo y es perfectamente comprensible sin necesidad de buscar información exterior. Además, es más extensa y más emotiva que en Ori and the blind forest. con varios momentos muy memorables que me hicieron llorar en mis primeras tres partidas (Tal vez soy un poco, o bueno, bastante sensible frente a cualquier mamada que incluya una criaturita peludita sufriendo en la vida). 

Must play, necesitas jugar esto si te gusta el género. Yo no me arrepiento de nada. Encima existen creaciones de fans como "The will to continue" por IHC, que van más profundos en varios aspectos del juego, desarrollan más los personajes dentro y fuera del canon y hacen de este maravilloso mundo de Ori algo incluso más memorable y emotivo.

Lo amé, cada segundo de él. (Excepto sacar el logro "Inmortal", ese me sacó varias canas).

144989524.review:
One of the best games I've played this year, hands down. This game has gotten enough praise so I'll just keep it short. 
Combat is really fun. Not on the level of Dead Cells fun (still my favourite metroidvania) but still some superb, top tier stuff. I especially enjoyed pairing that ability which lets you shoot arrows faster with that one ability which lets you shoot multiple short range burst arrows. 
Graphics wise, this game takes the cake, and should honestly be a standard for 2D platformers. The game is just beautiful to look at. I will leave it at that. 
Story wise, I think it was solid, like an 8.5 out of 10. Some parts I would most certainly change, but overall it wasn't drawn out a whole lot, and the run time felt good for the price of the game. Some of the puzzles were quite tricky (most of which I had to find guides on how to do them on YouTube) but they were genuinely well designed and fun to go through, though challenging at times. 
Overall, a very fun platformer that I think can appeal to anyone. If you've never played a 2D platformer game before, this could be a good choice.

144983695.review:
I've been playing platform games since the original Pitfall, circa 1982.  And now over 40 years later, I'm realizing that these aged hands no longer have the motor co-ordination and dexterity to keep up.  Therefore, after finishing Ori and the Will of the Wisps - I have decided that I am resigning from platform games.  No more.  This is it.  

And so since Ori here is the last platform game I'll ever play - it was an absolutely wonderful farewell.   Ori and the Will of the Wisps has encompassed forty years of platform gaming evolution and was an absolute delight to play ... just like Pitfall was back in 1982.    

Thank you, Ori - for making me experience - for the last time - the sheer simple pure joy of a platformer game.    I couldn't have asked for a better one.

144750040.review:
a bit late but; 
The great:
Smooth gameplay, revised and expanded abilitiy/movement systems from the first game, much larger map, and absolutely gorgeous visuals and animation (the new, and more plentiful cutscenes were always a treat). This time without optimization issues!

The good:
More chores via side quests but that's meh at worst, and up to personal preference. Though it is fun unlocking all the new stuff by completing them and really pays off when it comes to the harder challenges you get to after (I didn't even get close to completing them all).
Story isn't anything extraordinary from one casual playthrough, but doesn't need to be either. It's very wholesome and touching at times, and the villain(s) are genuinely intimidating, both through presentation and fight difficulty. It does what it needs to and ties the whole game together very nicely.

The meh:
could just be me being dumb but I don't get why, storywise, Ori would lose most of his abilities from the first game and we have to get them back here? Not a big issue since the player progression feels really good nonetheless, in my experience and opinion.

The bad:

Genuinely no significant complaints off the top of my head. I got this on sale but it's still well worth it for full price today.

144059892.review:
This game is very similar to its predecessor.  Unfortunately.

The graphics, music, and sound are amazing.  The platforming is quite good as well.  The combat is better than the last game, but still very weak.  As I said in the last game, they should have made a platformer rather than try and be a metroid-esq game.  

The last boss is the best example of that.  First, there is no enemy anywhere near as hard as this at any point in the game.  You go from decent combat with abilities you can work with to the mess the last boss is.

The game shows you where an attack is coming from, but never shows you what the actual hitbox is.  I kept getting his by the ground stomps because I would move just outside of the where the head would be to get some hits in.  Neither the head nor the marker on the ground are anywhere near the size of the hit.  That head is another example.  I could stand a full Ori width away from the head, but still get hurt when I tried to attack it.  The last phase shows the really bad design.  The projectiles come at you with pure RNG.  This means you can use them to keep up, but suddenly, the direction you were moving in from them becomes empty and the nearest one is literally on the other side of the screen.  This will kill you through no fault of your own.

Really, if they left out the combat and only did platforming, it would be a truly amazing game.

144056869.review:
I don't have as much to say about this game as I had for the first game, but that's simply because this game has much less to criticize. While the emotional impact this game's story had on me was not as substantial as Blind Forest's story, I still loved every second of it. The pacing of the ending was also a lot more well done, as well, with a very long and exciting buildup to the final boss fight. While this wasn't a complaint of mine, I've heard a lot of people say that Blind Forest's ending was very abrupt.

At first, I was a bit annoyed at how much this game was taking directly from Hollow Knight. I felt like those mechanics were Hollow Knight's own, and that no other game deserved to take them and use them for themselves. By the end, though, I really started to appreciate how much the gameplay benefited from the intense swordplay, charm system, and NPC-oriented quests, all mechanics that also appeared in Hollow Knight. Game studios taking inspiration from other games in their genre to better the overall experience is a very good thing, and while I didn't realize that at the start of my playthrough, I'm glad that Ori took this route.

The combat, abilities, charms, movement, and visuals are all a huge step up from the first game, with everything feeling just about perfect. This game will go down as one of the best Metroidvanias ever made, and I will certainly be replaying it for years to come.

But the frustration quickly gets cranked up to eleven, and for no good reason. What begins as a simple platformer turns into: Oh, you want to cross this room? You need to climb this wall, double jump away from it, dodge sideways in midair so you get close to a lantern, slingshot off it, pray you timed things right so you intercept an enemy projectile at the right point, slingshot off it, dodge sideways again at your apex to clear some spikes, then lasso a hook. 143615884.review:
[b]Sights & Sounds[/b]
- Like its prequel, this game is gorgeous. I found myself occasionally stopping to take in the backgrounds
- The characters still feel a little too small in proportion to the rest of the screen. This can be a boon on sequences that require careful planning, but I still felt like Ori was a bit tiny in some parts
- The music is amazing; the full score is comprised of well-performed orchestral pieces
- All the voice acting being done in a fantasy language makes it a little difficult to judge, but it seems mysterious and bassy enough

[b]Story & Vibes[/b]
- The story is as mysterious and symbolic as ever. You'll have to explore, collect items, and complete missions to get a better feel for the game world
- It's worth it to dig in a little bit. It makes the ending that much more poignant if you know what's going on
- In all, if you played the first game and made an effort to remember the bigger plot points, the story here is pretty good and provides great closure to the series
- The vibes oscillate between cute, mysterious, and scary

[b]Playability & Replayability[/b]
- Like the first game, this is a masterclass in metroidvania puzzle platforming. It's hard and you'll die a lot, but it never feels cheap or impossible. If we're going to continue comparing it to the first game, I'd say Will of the Wisps is a bit less challenging than Blind Forest
- This is a subjective opinion (aren't they all?), but I found myself enjoying the level design a bit more in this game. Areas like the little grove with all your friends and the watermill were really interesting. It's not that they were bad in Blind Forest. On the contrary, the level design and map were excellent there too. I just found myself having an easier time making a connection between my unlocked abilities and the places they allow me to access this time around
- There's way fewer chase and stealth sequences this time around. I was happy for the reduction while I was going through the story, but I wound up actually wishing there had been a few more of each as I was watching the credits roll
- The bosses were also pretty good, but won't pose much trouble if you've gotten the hang of beating bosses in more combat-intensive metroidvanias like Blasphemous, Grime, or Salt & Sanctuary
- I'll probably play both games in the series again one day. They're too good to not revisit sometime again

[b]Overall Impressions & Performance[/b]
- No performance issues or bugs to report
- I found myself liking Will of the Wisps just a little more than Blind Forest. If it comes down to any specific thing, I'd say it's the design involved in the watermill area. It's the best environment in either game in my opinion, and I had a blast exploring it

[b]Final Verdict[/b]
- [b]9/10[/b]. The Ori series gets a fitting and beautiful ending. Seriously, if you like Metroidvanias with challenging platforming, this series is can't-miss. Sure, it's not as complete a package as something like Hollow Knight, but I wouldn't rank Will of the Wisps far behind it

143526778.review:
I don't how they did it , but they made it even better than the first one.
When I played the first game , I enjoyed it a lot, it had everything a game has to offer : great story, interesting cutscenes,great music, amazing art,great game mechanics, a functioning upgrade system etc. 

After finishing the first one , I thought the sequel wouldnt get any better than that, boy was I so wrong.Here are the great improvements I think they made over the first game :

-Fighting : First game did have good mechanics, but fighting was ok , most of the time I would evade from fighting with creatures .However with this game, they improved the animations greatly, you can do 2-3 combos mid-air, when you give damage to enemies, enemies do show that they were attacked etc.I think they were many feedbacks regarding about this and they improved it into this wonderful mechanic.

-Upgrade System : This is also something I think they changed it for the better. In the first game , upgrades were in a menu which you can access through your latest save point. This made it easy to access from everywhere which was good but the upgrades were this tree-like structure which branches out to three distinct branches and if you wanted to get a spesific upgrade on a branch , you had to obtain the previous upgrades in order to do so -chain like- . So an upgrade like triple jump was only available late-game (you could receive it mid game but then you probably had to not upgrade the other branches to receive it).
In this game ,they removed the saving points completely. Game auto-saves now and I think this was a needed change because let's face it , manual saving sucks (or I suck at it lol). And since they removed manual saving ,instead of this  upgrade menu ,they turned it into a merchant where you can buy the upgrades from. And they also made it limited to a certain amount of slot (3 at start but could be extended to 8) so that it cant be used all at once but you can remove the upgrades from slot and replace it with another one easily.Since the slots are extendable , once you are late game , you could have sufficient amount of slots to beat the game etc. Overall this felt like a great change .

-Quick Travel : This was also a vital addition which was given to player's desire.In the first game, you could only quick travel when you reach into one of those pools where you can warp from one pool to another. But sometimes you would be far off from one and getting there could be time-consuming for some players. With this addition, you could warp to the any pools around the map so that you don't need to walk all the way to get to nearest pool and then warp.That was a nice touch.

-Open World : First game was also an open world-game but lacked the open world features and felt empty walking around the map -objective wise- . Second game however, turned this vast area into a better open world style and added some RPG features. In this game , you could get side quests apart from the main ones , and this helps with exploring the map, finding areas that are not mandatory to find, extending gameplay length etc. I finished the first game without exploring a huge area that had 2 upgrades which would have helped me better with exploring the rest of the map and was essential in obtaining some of the upgrades which I couldn't obtain because i lacked those upgrades.
As I mentioned before, merchants instead of upgrade trees or buying the map from a vendor instead of activating the map yourself breaks the feeling of being alone in a huge area where it doesn't make sense to not have any living beings around. This was a great change that put the game on a even higher level than it normally is.

The only thing i would reproach about is the main gameplay - playing the main quests- , had it not been the boss fights, It pretty much felt like doing the same thing in the first game. Go to that area, grab that thing, go to the other are and grab the other thing; once you have it all collected, go to boss area , fight the boss etc.Only difference was the boss fights and not gonna lie , boss fights were much better than the  tree sections of the first game.But this was something that is mildy annoying and didn't effect my opinion about this game .
That being said, I think my overall ranking of this game would be 9/10.

143489054.review:
Simply put, this is the best game I have ever played.  And that says a lot as I've played quite a few.

My first real video game experience was playing Rayman 1 on the PS1, then later Rayman 2: The Great Escape and Rayman 3: Hoodlum Havoc on my old Gateway computer.  This was accompanied by the Crash Bandicoot Trilogy and and the first couple Spyro games on the PS1.  Rayman was my favorite though: the mysterious and magical primordial forrest and whimsical characters and (slightly) dark plot elements and wonderful music had me in love.

I grew up, and played other games (mostly FPS and RPGs), and I longed for a game to fill the hole the Rayman franchise left in me, as most other platforming games just weren't the same.

Then I discovered Ori.  I played through Ori and The Blind Forrest, and what a wonderful surreal experience!  It felt like fresh air, and gave me feelings I hadn't felt since I was a kid.  So naturally, I played Ori and the Will of the Wisps.

It was every bit as good as the first Ori game, and actually improved some aspects that were lacking in the first game. It's improved graphics will be harder on older systems, but the game is even more vivid than the first game (which is impressive!).  Punchy controls, fun and engaging mechanics, and beautiful story and soundtrack make this game one of the best experiences I've ever had playing a game.

143340881.review:
id like to go over some of the main changes coming form blind forest, which, if you haven't played that yet i strongly recommend it before playing this. experiencing the story of blind forest enhances the experience of the story for will of the wisps substantially.

and if you have played blind forest and enjoyed it, this game is a quality sequel that follows the spirit of blind forest enough that i would bet you will enjoy it too

of course, will of the wisps still has some phenomenal art and music, and the story is just as beautiful as blind forest and i recommend both games on principle for that story.

one of the main differences between blind forest and will of the wisps is the inclusion of an actual, far more in depth combat system and i love it. combat feels just as fluid and satisfying as the platforming and is very moment centric. the game still isnt as combat focused as something like hollow knight or anything but its very enjoyable regardless and just like blind forest enemies still play into the platforming itself still which i also like.

speaking of the platforming, the gameplay's main focus id say is probably still platforming and it feels polished up a bit from blind forest, who's moment already felt very fluid and satisfying.

will of the wisps still has what i call "chase sequences" for lack of a better term that i talked about in my review for blind forest, in short it is a hazard or similar obstacle that progresses through an area and you have to stay ahead of it. they are challenging platforming sequences that are extremely gratifying to complete and satisfying to move through, and are some of my favorite moments in both games

beyond combat and platforming, will of the wisps also introduces NPCs and side quests along with its normal life/energy collectibles which i greatly enjoyed. the quests arent really tedious and usually just gives you an opportunity to learn more about the world and the people in it, if only just a little. it serves to make the world feel more alive.

will of the wisps is also a much longer game than blind forest despite my playtime for both being roughly similar (i have a lot of afk time lol). i completed blind forest in roughly 10-12 hours and i completed will of the wisps 100% in roughly 20-22. the areas are larger and more detailed and nuanced and there are more things to collect and find and do than blind forest.

~~~~~~[h1][u][b]FULL REVIEW[/b][/u][/h1]~~~~~~
The first Ori game was great but it was that, just a fun and worthwhile experience for time spent and price paid.
What the hell was this game.
They completely reinvented the gameplay while improving everything that made the first game good, that being the soundtrack, style/graphics, and the narrative.
It's unreal how fluid playing it is, it genuinely feels like it's not real, like it shouldn't exist, but it's just that good.
Ori controls beautifully, and the upgrades to his moveset make you feel incredibly satisfied after pulling off some insane parkour, MVPs being the amazing chase sequences.
They also made the combat far better, following the Hollow Knight system of shards that you can equip to your playstyle, that complement not only Ori's combat but also his moveset (like a triple jump).
The weapons are also diverse, though I only found myself using the heavy hammer, the sword and the arrow, but that's just my playstyle, yours will probably be much different.
The story while not God of War levels, made me cry, very hard, at multiple points, I genuinely feel for this world and its characters, and the ending is a masterpiece.
The soundtrack doesn't follow the usual "Not the focus until a boss battle or emotional moment", I found myself stopping just to listen to the overworld soundtrack because of how beautiful it is, it elevates the experience by that much.
Genuinely a masterpiece.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an absolute masterpiece that left me emotionally charged from start to finish. The heart-wrenching story pulled me in with its touching narrative, weaving a tale of friendship, sacrifice, and growth that resonated deeply with my soul. From the very first moments, I found myself emotionally invested in Ori's journey, experiencing a rollercoaster of emotions that only a truly remarkable game can evoke.

The gameplay is a flawless blend of excitement and refinement. Navigating through the beautifully designed environments felt smooth and fluid, while the various challenges and puzzles kept me constantly engaged and thrilled. The developers have truly outdone themselves, creating a gameplay experience that is both challenging and rewarding, leaving me hungry for more after each gaming session.

Visually, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a breathtaking wonderland. The stunning graphics and attention to detail brought this fantastical world to life in ways I couldn't have imagined. Every frame was a work of art, and the game's visual beauty complemented the emotional depth of the story perfectly, resulting in an unforgettable and immersive experience.

In conclusion, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an outstanding package that exceeds all expectations. With its heart-rending story, captivating gameplay, and mesmerizing visuals, this game has set a new standard for excellence in the gaming industry. I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone seeking an unforgettable and emotionally enriching gaming adventure. Bravo to the developers for creating a true masterpiece!

142659194.review:
Short Summary: 10/10
Much like it's predecessor, Ori and the Will of the Wisps (WotW) is visually and musically stunning, and continues the story shorty after Ori and the Blind Forest (BF) left off.  The biggest distinction I can make between the two games is that in WotW, Ori feels more powerful and accompanied by friendly faces in an otherwise harsh world, whereas in BF, Ori felt much more frail, isolated and alone.  Nonetheless, the world of WotW is just as threatening and vast as BF.  Will of the Wisps is a worthy successor to Blind Forest, and well worth a playthrough!

The Full Summary:
WotW retains the charm and beauty that made me fall in love with BF, but this time around, Ori feels like they've grown since the last adventure.  While still very much a Metroidvania-style platform adventure, combat is much more heavily emphasized here than in BF.  Throughout WotW, Ori gains a plethora of upgradable powers that make exploration and combat a breeze. 

Also unlike BF, this world is inhabited by friendly faces.  This takes away from the sense of isolation, hopelessness and dread that gave BF such a distinct feel, but nevertheless Ori still feels like this world's last hope, seeing as how many of the inhabitants of this place mention that they haven't seen a Light Spirit like Ori in their area for a very long time.  This is also emphasized whenever you stray too far from the central hub area, as much of the terrain is dark, desolate, and dangerous. 

While the above does change the flavor of the game when compared to its predecessor, this is still very much an Ori game at it's core and plays just as smoothly as BF.  And personally I appreciated having a friendly, more alive world to explore.  The ally creatures, and even some enemies, reveal backstory and lore, making the world feel much more fleshed out.  It makes it feel like you're fighting to protect something in WotW, whereas in BF you were fighting to restore what was lost.  

The story was a delight to play through, and finding every collectible and side-quest was a nice challenge on top of the story.  There are also Combat Shrines and Spirit Trials that test your combat and platforming prowess, respectively.  So there's plenty to do if you need a break from questing. 

Will of the Wisps is a fantastic follow-up to Blind Forest, and absolutely worth a play through, especially if Metroidvania-style games are your thing.

142438677.review:
I rate games on a 1-5 scale a la X-PLAY (no decimals)

5/5

Definitely an improvement over the first game especially in regard to the mechanics. I can definitely tell this game copied Hollow Knight in regard to the “spirit shards” which are essentially “charms.” The combat is far more enjoyable and not repetitive like the first game and the different environments is a lot more fun this go around. This game definitely had more challenge to it as well. I also enjoy the fact that I could 100% the game without needed a strategy guide. Only once or twice I had to look up for some help in regard to getting to a new area.

Overall, it addressed my gripes about the first game in a lot of creative ways. It also made escape scenes a bit more forgiving and less time consuming. Really the only knock I have on the game is that it certainly copied aspects from Hollow Knight. I wish it wasn’t so overt in doing so but I will say the game stands on its own just fine. The general story and new characters are enjoyable as well.

I can’t sit here and say it’s better than Hollow Knight but the gap between the two is not much. This is arguably easier to pick up and adapt to as it still is not as hard and allows for traveling and ease of getting around much easier. The strength of the game is platforming and that is something that I can’t say any other game can compare to because of how downright fun and complicated the platforming can get. It’s hard to find anything to not like about this game truthfully. It’s quite enjoyable and did something that few sequels do and managed to improve the obvious flaws from the first while not changing the formula too much.

142368503.review:
I remember watching a YouTube video that compared this game to Hollow Knight—their conclusion was that these games have many similarities, but rather than copying from Hollow Knight, the leader of Moon Studios (team that made Ori) thought he could do better than Team Cherry (team that made Hollow Knight). Ironically, throughout my experience playing this game, the thought of "Hollow Knight did this better" was usually at the back of my mind.

Hollow Knight doesn't have 3D models; instead it has fantastic artwork, tight controls, and challenging gameplay.

Ori's aesthetic is similar, but it's more 3D and your character has inertia: I literally spent a good 4 or 5 minutes trying to jump onto a small platform because of this.

Ori also gives you a lot more text to read. In Hollow Knight, you can collect a Mask Shard, Vessel Fragment, or other important item, and there's little to no descriptive text, because none is needed—everything in that game is intuitive. By contrast, every time I got an item in Ori, they gave me a lengthy explanation about what it does and how I should get ready to collect a bunch more of them. I'm sure not everyone will feel this way, and I'm probably making a huge deal out of something that's not very important, but for me it felt like I was being patronized.

I can respect the opinion of anyone who enjoys this game (and/or its predecessor), but it wasn't for me.

142252368.review:
Ori and the Will of The Wisps es un juegazo. Si ya Ori and the Blind Forest era un juego sobresaliente, esta secuela dice "quien sos" y mejora en todo lo mejorable a su precuela. Si bien al principio, puede sentirse un poco secuela continuista, a lo largo de la aventura te das cuenta de que es algo distinto, pero en el mismo universo. Vamos a desgranar todo.

El mapa de su precuela no terminó de encantarme. Pues este juego soluciona todos los problemas que mencioné (como la mucha linealidad para un metroidvania) y añade un montón de cosas por hacer. Y sí, son UN MONTÓN. En el mapa, habrá NPCs que tendrán distintas funciones: algunos mandarán "rumores" (que son unas mini misiones secundarias de ver un lugar), otros te darán mejoras u objetos a cambio de dinero y otros tendrán funciones muy marcadas, como venderte mapas, darte misiones secundarias o darte cosas a cambio de otra moneda. Solo con esto, ya mejoran muchísimo el mapa, porque te dan a conocer que hay más gente. Además, hay una especie de santuarios en los que por pruebas te dan dinero, que expande más la exploración.

Jugablemente, es increíble. Los controles son igual de fluidos que los de su precuela, pero añade una cantidad de mecánicas a las del juego base, que acostumbrarse al anterior después de haberlo jugado será muy difícil. Son muy variadas y consiguen que tanto el movimiento como el combate de este juego sean una maravilla. Esto sumado a una especie de sistema de amuletos como el de Hollow Knight, expande las posiblidades hasta el infinito.

Las boss-fights son muy buenas, pero hay muy pocas. Todas siguen un sistema parecido (que no destriparé aquí) pero se sienten muy diferentes entre sí y son muy difíciles, por lo que el hecho de hacerlas bien, es un logro increíble. Las mazmorras se echan de menos, habiendo solo 2 en todo el juego pero las que hay están diseñadas de manera excelente.

Audiovisualmente es lo único en lo que no se podía mejorar a la precuela. Es igual de bonito, tiene entornos muy variados de aspecto y de colores (diferenciando los elementos con colores característicos) y el diseño de personajes, enemigos y jefes es increíble. La OST es para ir a la casa de cada uno de los compositores y felicitarles individualmente. Algunas canciones son obras de arte que llegan al corazón.

Si bien la historia no es lo que más destaca del juego, está bastante bien. Tiene algún giro que nadie se esperaría y que a algunos podría llegar a sacarles lagrimillas. Toca temas muy parecidos a los de la precuela, y hace una narrativa bastante buena.

Resumiendo, Ori and the Will of the Wisps es un juegazo (casi obra maestra) que perfecciona a su precuela en todo lo perfeccionable que tenía. Recomendadísimo
