142149375.review:
A solid 7/10 game (9/10 presentation, 6/10 actual game) that shines in it's visual and audio design, and packs some fun platforming challenges to boot. I felt the combat fell a little flat for me, and the world did feel a little empty towards the end of the game, but I ended up enjoying it nevertheless. There are a couple games that get a better value for the $30 pricetag, but I ended up snagging it on sale and enjoyed my time with it. Worth your time if you can get it for cheaper.

This is my first time playing a game in this series, and I ended up 100% it on Normal. I might revisit it for the Speedrun achievements or to play it again on Hard, but I don't really feel a strong urge to do so.

PROS:
- The game is visually stunning. Backgrounds look phenomenal, and the various details like the flora in each region help sell the game's world. The character animation is also incredibly good, both in gameplay and in cutscenes, doing a good job of selling emotion without dialogue. I wish more games looked like this.
- The Sound and the Music of the game is also fantastic. A lot of work was evidently put into both the sound design for gameplay and the score for the game, and it really shines through. It reminded me a lot of the Armello SFX, which are also amazing.
- The platforming feels REALLY good. The game gives you access to a lot of things that just chain together really well, and I think the complexity really works in its favor. Plus, I'm a sucker for anything bullet time, and bash tickles my monkey brain in a lot of different ways.
- This game feels OK to 100%? There's not that much content, sure, but I'm grateful there's no 40+ minute endurance challenges or esoteric puzzles that I have to bash my head into for hours to solve. I do wish there was some more variety, but fully completing the game doesn't feel actively bad, which I enjoy.

CONS:
- Combat feels like an afterthought. Enemy variety is pretty low (I can think of maybe like 4 distinct non-boss enemies? There's a couple of variants but you get my point) and normal enemies never really feel like a barrier after a certain point. This game also gives you a ton of flat combat buffs (do more damage, etc.) that make the game easier without making it more fun/interesting.
- Bosses were also super disappointing. None of them really feel engaging, and the game does a poor job of communicating both when you get hit and when you hit the boss back. 
-  Some late-game abilities kind of trivialize a lot of the platforming challenges, which is both a blessing and a curse. It makes traversing the map a lot faster and more fun, but also takes a lot of the puzzle solving out of the equation. Wish there were a few limits on it (use energy or something idk).
- I didn't really mesh with the story at all. Part of this may be the fact that I didn't play the first game, but I never really got super compelled by the main story. You don't really get to interact with a lot of the main forces opposing you outside of hearing other people talk about how bad they are, which feels a little flat from a storytelling perspective.
- The game is noticeably buggy. Several memory leaks just happen throughout my playthrough, and lag leading to input delay was also a thing that happens sometimes. For a game that is so polished otherwise, that was kind of shocking to me.
- For a Metroidvania, it feels like backtracking is very underutilized. Never felt the need to go back to older areas until I was already trying to 100% the game. I think the game would have benefited if they had cut a few areas and put that effort into bulking up the remaining areas with more secrets, quests, and puzzles.

This game felt very casual on my playthrough. Dying is never really a setback and you almost always have the resources needed to accomplish something nearby. This could be a positive or a negative depending on who you talk to, but it was definitely very prominent in my mind when I was playing through the game. The game is at its best as a platformer, the movement is well thought out and engaging and the map design helps accentuate the game's strengths. The combat feels very straightforward and would be where I would want to see the most improvement in a potential sequel. This game's presentation is a standout quality - the animation and visuals are heads and shoulders above other similar games. It was a good experience and I would recommend it to anyone interested in trying a new 2D platforming/exploration game.

142134525.review:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an absolute masterpiece that enchants players with its breathtaking visuals, mesmerizing music, and an emotional journey that will leave an everlasting impression. From the very first moment I stepped into its magical world, I was captivated by the sheer beauty and attention to detail that permeates every aspect of the game.

The graphics in Ori and the Will of the Wisps are a true work of art. The hand-painted environments burst with vibrant colors and lush landscapes, creating a living and breathing world that feels alive in every frame. From the swaying grass to the shimmering waterfalls, every pixel is meticulously crafted with love and care. The animations are fluid and expressive, bringing the characters and creatures to life in a way that feels both natural and fantastical. It's a visual feast that constantly surprised and delighted me, making every new area a joy to explore.

Complementing the stunning visuals is a musical score that is nothing short of sublime. The haunting melodies and atmospheric compositions perfectly capture the mood and emotions of each scene. Whether it's the gentle piano keys during a moment of tranquility or the crescendo of orchestral triumph during an intense encounter, the music in Ori and the Will of the Wisps elevates the entire experience to new heights. It tugs at your heartstrings and immerses you deeper into the world, creating an emotional connection that is truly profound.

Beyond its audiovisual splendor, the gameplay in Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a joyous and satisfying experience. The platforming mechanics are precise and intuitive, allowing for graceful movements and exhilarating traversal through the intricately designed levels. The controls are responsive, empowering you to navigate through challenging obstacles with ease and grace. The combat is engaging, requiring strategic thinking and skillful execution to overcome formidable enemies. The game strikes a perfect balance between exploration, puzzle-solving, and thrilling action, ensuring that every moment spent in its world is filled with wonder and excitement.

But what truly sets Ori and the Will of the Wisps apart is its ability to tug at your heartstrings. The narrative is beautifully crafted, exploring themes of love, sacrifice, and the power of friendship. It weaves a heartfelt story that resonates deeply, and the emotional moments are delivered with such sincerity that they left me teary-eyed on more than one occasion. The characters are endearing and their relationships are beautifully portrayed, creating an emotional investment that makes the journey all the more impactful.

In conclusion, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a true gem of a game that excels in every aspect. Its stunning visuals transport you to a world of breathtaking beauty, while its enchanting music evokes a wide range of emotions. The gameplay is a delightful blend of precision platforming and thrilling combat, keeping you engaged and exhilarated throughout. Most importantly, the game touches your soul with its heartfelt story and memorable characters. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a must-play for anyone seeking a truly transcendent gaming experience. Prepare to be whisked away on an unforgettable journey.

Ori and the Will of the Wisps is an improvement upon the first game which I think speaks volumes about how good it is since sequels struggle to live up to the expectations from the first game. To keep it short, I am shocked by how good the story is with limited dialogue and as for the abilities its fantastic. The movement is incredibly smooth and super fun. The only downside to the movement is that it is a little cluttered in how many movement abilities there are. Its a little hard to manage how which abilities you need to use with how many there are. That is a minor gripe however because outside of that, the game is phenomenal and well worth the price. If you can get it on sale it is an absolute steal.

The only caveat I will make is that the game is short in game time compared to some titles. I logged 12 hours in grabbing the majority of the collectibles in the game and completing the story. Even if that makes you hesitant I would still suggest you give it a try as it truly is an incredible game that 100% worth it for me.

Problems

141674875.review:
The Blind Forest was a strong start for the Moon Studio team and WotW makes for a fine follow up. The game maintains the beautiful art style only getting more pretty by focusing more on bioluminescence and adding a more vivid depth to the world's environments that wobble and bounce in response to your movement. The music is also just as strong maintaining the emotive orchestral world-music score that compliments the game's primal tones.

Having already mastered movement the team decided to add more combat in this title. WotW does away with the ranged wisp attack and now introduces a small variety of weapons and a new cast of monsters to use them against. It lacks the mechanical precision of it's contemporaries and while the combat is there it isn't innovated on at all. The enemies are nothing special in terms of gameplay and you'll encounter the same few types throughout the entire game. There are a few different weapons but they feel like toys to play with, not tools to be applied to enemies. If anything they see more creative uses as solutions to puzzles and platforming sections than they do as ways to dispatch foes.

Movement meanwhile is still very strong and WotW introduces a handful of new movement abilities which compliment everything that came before. The cinematic boss platforming sections make a return but are accompanied by lacklustre boss fights that provide more excuses to use the attack button and don't add much else. You also get to play as Ku for a section of the game which makes for a nice change of pace, and offers a bit of unique movement and platforming.

As for story, if the first Ori game was about the cycles of life and death WotW is about growing up and playing your part in those cycles. The new characters and critters you befriend all seemed unnecessary seeing how the first game conjured so much emotion with zero dialogue, and the new quests they bring with them feel like blatant padding. I imagine the studio wanted to capitalise on making you run around and fight things, but it's a shame they resorted to some of the more phoned in game design to accomplish that.

In conclusion WotW does less with more but given the first game's strength was its minimalism there's no wonder they had trouble making all the new features fit. If the combat focus was treated with the same creativity as the first game's movement it could have really been something special rather than a middling sequel with lots of padding.

141162942.review:
What a fantastic game! I have played it through to it's conclusion and enjoyed every minute of it.

The cuts scenes are great and tell the story very well. The game is nicely paced, split into different missions, each with their own story and boss fights at the end. In between those you explore the maze-like worlds avoiding various dangers and fighting off all sorts of creatures searching for various items which you need to upgrade your abilities and progress the story.

Plenty of action and some of the boss fights were a genuine challenge.

I came across this game after looking for something similar to Rayman Legends so if you enjoyed that, you will likely enjoy "Ori and the Will of the Wisps".

I would highly recommend this game.

This is the first time I can say I've genuinely disliked or even hated a game. The story was okay, started off great and just went downhill. The art is fine, and the controls are meh. Half the skills are extremely hard to use, or straight up don't work the way they're meant to. You mess up even one second of a challenge and you may as well restart the entire thing because you're not going to win it. There's no clear explanation of how half the things - INCLUDING THE CONTROLS - work. I literally had to google the PROLOGUE just to get past it. The ending sucked, although the story itself was nice. The controls were super horrible to use, even when changed around, especially as half of the skills just felt janky or slapped in when they didn't even work well. 
I will not be buying a game from this producer again if this is what all their games are going to be like. Tip for people who like to relax while playing a game or take it easy on the first round; just don't buy this. It's not worth it at all, all it brings is fustration over things that just don't work.

140966080.review:
As much as i enjoyed the first Ori game am I now enjoying the second part.

Everything that was said about the original Quadriple A platformer game from MOON studios, can also be said about the Will of the Wisps.

Great story, great graphics, fantastic soundscore, perfect handling, superb gameplay... I just can't find anything bad about these two games... The first game left such a big impression on me that after 8 years I immediately remembered what all happened "before" during the introduction of the new story.

If I had to chose a "benchmark" for platformer games, then without any doubt i'd say that the Ori games are by a landslide the best games to perform this task flawlessly.

The only regret i have is that I waited such a long time before picking up the second game... But that's what you get with a Steam backlog that's literally thousands of games big!

If you like platformer games, then this game is a direct hit on your joy-synapses; you'll never regret buying this game...

140940795.review: I enjoyed this game, more than the Blind Forest. It improved significantly on the level design, and made combat at the very least somewhat engaging. Near the end though, I felt the game began to overstay its welcome, as while the combat was alright, I really didn't like the boss fights. The story was good, it made me feel emotions, but if those boss fights were streamlined some more, or replaced by a chase or cut entirely, I would have felt far less frustration. If I were to say anything more, it would be that if you enjoy metroidvanias, you should play this game, but you should space it out a lot more than I did.

I think I prefer the Blind Forest because of its originality, but this is still excellent. Great music and visuals, as expected, and very fluid game-play. More of a combat focus on boss battles than the Blind Forest, which I didn't always enjoy, but I guess it's a change of pace. Some people praise the story, and there were some lore-drops near the end that revealed some stuff about the world, but despite it trying to be emotional it never really was for me. 

Overall very enjoyable. There's just something about slowly gathering those movement abilities until you're flying through areas you slowly struggled through in the early game. 

Oh, and the Moki. Those little critters are just adorable and always make me smile. 

Took my about 16 hours to finish the story and another 4 to finish up all collectables, spirit trials, etc.

140682202.review: Had this on my wishlist after seeing it was rated almost as well as Hollow Knight.  I'd agree with most people that it is almost as good as Hollow Knight.  The graphics are extremely impressive.  The different environments are all colorful and easy on the eyes.  The game feels like it's breathing with life, the background and characters and enemies all have a fluidity in the animation.  The game is fun to play and gets you pretty addicted once you start.  I like how you can choose what weapons you'd like to play the game with.  You get a sword to use at the beginning, but you can choose to unequip it for any of the others (which you have to purchase from this monkey character).  I used the sword and hammer at the beginning without knowing much about which weapons would be good to purchase.  I found that fighting the bosses with melee was sorta difficult though.  A fully upgraded bow turned out to be my favorite in the end.  You can shoot up to five arrows and use a shard to increase fire speed and decimate pretty much anyone without much of an energy cost.  You'll spend most of the game jumping, double jumping dashing grappling in different ways over spiky pits or spiky walls.  None of the regular enemies proved too challenging, but they can be sorta an annoying distraction.  If you die in this game you have endless lives and they restart you close to where you died which is nice because if they took the dark souls approach this game would be brutal.  I think the main thing that sorta bothered me about this game is I found certain bosses to be extremely annoying.  It felt less predictable to fight them than other games.  The bosses give little clues to what attack is coming, but sometimes even when you know what they'll do you still can't avoid getting hit.  The last boss has an ending phase that's absolutely nuts and I couldn't imagine how anyone could make it through without dying at least once.  The first two phases aren't bad at all, but then it just goes crazy and you're grappling desperately while getting hit rapidly from different directions where if you're in one large area of the screen you can't possibly dodge.  Then you have to continue grappling and somehow get hits in and then go back to grappling and getting hit some more.  I found the best weapon for this last phase is the exploding spike because you can shoot from far away and deal great damage.  But you have to conserve your energy up to that point if you want to use it, otherwise you'll end up having to use melee in this phase.

Though I bought it on sale, but its astounding soundtracks and beautifully crafted metroidvania genre definitely make it more worthy. I even cried for the cutscene in the end *Poor ori, sob sob. 10/10

✨As an avid player of platform-adventure games, Ori and the Will of the Wisps struck me with its captivating world and emotionally charged gameplay. From start to finish, this sequel transports you into a realm of breathtaking beauty and heartwarming storytelling.


Story📖:
✨Ori and the Will of the Wisps weaves a profoundly moving narrative that tugs at the heartstrings while exploring themes of friendship, loss, and the indomitable spirit of resilience. The story immerses players in a world brimming with emotion and leaves a lasting impact long after the game is over.


Graphics🖼️:
✨The hand-painted visuals in Ori and the Will of the Wisps are nothing short of mesmerizing. Each frame is a work of art👨‍🎨, meticulously crafted to evoke a sense of wonder and immersion. From lush forests to haunting caves, every corner of the game is a stunning display of color, lighting, and attention to detail.


Game Mechanics⚙️:
✨The platforming mechanics in Ori and the Will of the Wisps are fluid and responsive, making every jump and dash feel satisfyingly precise. New abilities and upgrades that enhance the gameplay, allowing for creative exploration and strategic combat. The level design is ingeniously crafted, offering challenging yet rewarding puzzles and exhilarating chase sequences.


Game World🍄:
✨Niwen, the forest realm where the game takes place, is a character in itself. It is a sprawling, interconnected world filled with hidden secrets 🗝, diverse environments, and fascinating creatures. From the towering trees of the Silent Woods to the ethereal glow of the Wellspring Glades, exploring Niwen feels like stepping into a living, breathing painting.


Soundtrack📀:
✨The enchanting soundtrack of Ori and the Will of the Wisps complements the game's atmosphere perfectly. The melodies range from hauntingly melancholic to uplifting and triumphant, weaving seamlessly with the narrative and enhancing emotional moments🎼. 


🌟Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a masterpiece that transcends the boundaries of gaming. With its breathtaking graphics, tight gameplay mechanics, soul-stirring soundtrack, and a world that begs to be discovered, it is a journey that will leave you captivated from the first moment🌠.
♡₊˚ 🦢・₊✧

140665460.review: Ori and the Blind Forest was awesome, so I checked this game out too. And it blew my mind! The graphics are 20 times better than the previous game's (Already awesome) graphics, and the combat is much better too! As while the first game's combat (Though great in its own right) usually amounted to mash the attack button while dodging the enemy's attacks, and maybe occasionally use the bash or ground pound attack when you unlock them, Will of the Wisps' combat is much more in-depth. There are multiple weapons to pick from, more ways to attack, and the combat feels a lot better overall! As for the world map, it's absolutely humongous! And yet it still manages to be easy to navigate! The game also features actual boss fights, unlike the first game, which only really had 1 miniboss, and a bunch of chase-sequences. The boss fights in this game are great too,  and since this game has multiple different weapons to pick from, the boss fights have a lot of strategy to them too! But even though this game has actual boss fights, it also has chase sequences like the first game. And they are just as great if not better than the first game's! This game also has actual NPCs, and sidequests, unlike the first game. Notably, the characters, and sidequests are really in-depth, like for example, if a character at one point mentions having moved from a different area of the map, leaving their old house behind, the old house will actually be located at that part on the map! This results in the world feeling a lot more alive than the previous game's. Honestly, my only complaint with this game is that it has a few audio issues in a few places (though that's probably due to my bad graphics card), but that didn't really impact the experience as a whole, so while the first game was awesome, this game is epic! And it's very much a must-play for any metroidvania fan out there, even more than the first game!

Ori and the Will of the Wisps surpass its predecessor, Ori and the Blind Forest, in every aspect, delivering an extraordinary gaming experience. 
It's graphically better. Visuals and artistic environments immerse players in a vibrant and enchanting world. 
The narrative is filled with emotional depth and memorable characters from the previous game, adding another layer of richness to the game. 
Combat mechanics have been enhanced, offering a satisfying and dynamic gameplay experience. 
Ori's mobility has been expanded too, granting players a greater sense of freedom and fluidity in movement. 
Additionally, the game features a larger map full of hidden secrets. 
In summary, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a masterpiece and a must-play in the platforming genre.

140343457.review:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a wonderful game.
Ori and the Blind Forest was already a master piece. Nevertheless, the sequel really surpassed its predecessor.
Everything about this game is right.
The music might be one of the biggest accomplishments of Moon Studios.
The story is superb, although very sad. 
The levels and environments are gorgeous.
The playability is very smooth and responsive.
The way the developers expanded the Ori's abilities is very well done.

In summary, if you are thinking if you should buy this game or not, I believe that if you liked the first, you are going to love the second, so just get it, enjoy it, and, maybe, cry a little.

Ori and the will of the wisps is a master piece.

The only thing that might have caused me a little conflict, is the localisation part in LATAM.
Now, I have to admit that I did not play the game in Spanish, I was just curious about the localisation part, so I set the game to Spanish after I finished it. I just wanted to check a few strings here and there.
In my opinion, some words, or even sentences were not translated to reflect the real or full potential of the story, therefore, sometimes these little issues watered down an already extremely good story.
Nevertheless, these issues, if they are indeed issues, are/ could be easily fixed.

Just dive in and enjoy this beauty!

Magnificent graphics, awesome soundtrack, extremely smooth platforming - basically the same good ol' Ori but with lots of developments:
- More platforming mechanics, all of them engaging and well executed
- More developed combat system with several different weapons and proper boss fights.
- Character progression with swappable perks, so that you can adapt to different situations.
- The world is populated with NPCs and a good number of side activities so it is more dense with content than the predecessor.

So yeah, what was already a great game here is bigger and tastier. But not without drawbacks. Combat and progression of course are now a bit deeper and give more agenda to the player, but there is rarely an incentive to try a different weapon or a perk set. And while story is more evenly distributed throughout the game, empasising NPCs, an overarching narrative is somewhat lacking.

But still, it is a very good game and I highly recommend it to everyone. And if you haven't played the Blind Forest - do that too.

An incredible game. It's beautiful, heartwarming, and the perfect level of challenging. While it is very akin to Hollow Knight in it's entirety, it has several unique additions and extra quality of life things Hollow Knight was missing. The navigation of the map was superior, you don't need to waste your passive buff slots with items just to navigate the map. It even provided automatic map icons for optional collectibles so you can easily return to the spot when you get that biome's movement upgrade. AND it has maps you can buy or unlock that show you all the secret upgrades in the game for any achievement hunters like myself. The achievements felt appropriately difficult, requiring a solid understanding and skill for the game without too much playtime required if you're efficient.
The graphics are beautiful and varied. The cut-scenes are emotional and do a great job portraying emotional scenes with very minimal dialogue. Overall it was a wonderful experience and I don't regret my money spent at all.

TL;DR: This game is a master piece. and I would absolutely recommend it to anyone into video games. Awesome story, Awesome gameplay.

The story is perfectly written with the right amount of drive to keep you playing the game trying to discover how it will end. The ending is beautiful and the journey along the game is very interesting with a lot of npc characters that are unique and entertaining. 
The game play is highly entertaining with your power scaling pretty significantly along the game. You will unlock a shit load of new skills and they are all useful and fun to use. Some skills are part of the main story and some skills are upgradable skills that are not necessary to complete the game but they are fun still. *the last skill you upgrade as a part of the main story is incredible fun*
The platforming is one of the best out there, you can't get a lot better than that. I love how the platforming feels as it keeps you entertained and engaged. The gameplay and the movements are very smooth and satisfying.
The combat is not necessarily the most important part of the game, yet the boss fights are really fun with different bosses.
The art style is very artistic, this stylized art is visually appealing and the music will give you eargasm and induce all kinds of emotions within you as you play the different parts of the game.
The map is great with a metroidvania that includes a lot of hidden places for completionists who like to collect every possible nugget in the game. you can always comeback to access hidden places that will be inaccessible for you on your first encounter.
It took me more than it should to complete the game because I've gotten stuck and went running around looking for solution more than I would like to admit. Yet the solutions were pretty easy when I have finally figured them out.

140002068.review:
A truly worthy sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest; Will of the Wisps takes everything I loved about the original game & dials it up a notch in depth & breadth, though it's not totally without fault.

Presentation isn't one of those faults. The game is a treat for the eyes in every sense, & if you're fortunate enough to own an OLED screen, this is absolutely the game you need to play to show it off. The incredibly detailed yet clean presentation allows for visuals that pop beautifully while sitting in the overall scene well. The OST also hits the mark, as does the story, which ties in beautifully to the Blind Forest.

The gameplay is brilliant, though there's definitely some inconsistency when it comes to difficulty. There's nothing here that'll cause much of a headache if you're a regular player of such games, but the increase in gameplay complexity compared to BF paired with a few oddly tuned boss fights make for an experience which can be a bit inconsistent at times.

Overall though, it's a spectacular sequel to a stunning game. A treat for your senses with wonderfully tight gameplay & a charming story that compliments Blind Forest perfectly.

"Will of the Wisps" is everything that made the first game so excellent only bigger, better, and with more features and polish.  The visuals and music are even more stunning. You unlock a wider variety of skills that take the platforming puzzles to the next level and make navigating the world even more of a joy. 139517720.review:
Edited Review:

Just beat the game, 100% of all items collected. This one is a masterclass of production, though it's not without occasional flaws.

Combat is a HUGE upgrade from the original, and is satisfying on so many levels. From silvery slashes to thundering hammer blows that knock enemies flying, every aspect of combat is delightful. There is an abundance of ways to attack that suit a variety of playstyles, but I'll be blunt when I say that not all available forms of attack are particularly useful to me. To each his/her own, there's lots of stuff for people to enjoy here. 

Graphics and environments are hugely updated and well developed. Gorgeous coloring and lighting are abundant. Periodically, there will be something that looks a little lazy, such as the splash animation that happens when pink blobs shoot out of a slimy pit, but those moments are few and far between. 

The level design is GORGEOUS. There are many places that are easy to "ooo" and "ahhh" at. Nothing I've ever played looks like this game. Truly unique. 

Story is much more developed than the first. Though stereotypical and not perfect in its writing or execution (e.g. "you're the hero that will save us"), it contains some beautiful cinematics and heartfelt scenes filled with deep emotion. The cinematics, like the graphics, are very unique in execution. 

The music, like the first, is SOOOOO GOOOD. Blind Forest moved me deeply with the music at the opening screen, and this game continues that motif. I bought the OST of the first one, and I'm planning on buying this one, too. There is a fair amount of "recycled" themes, as is pretty normal for sequels, but the composer came back with some new ideas on how to freshen up the themes while adding entirely new songs that fit the field and atmosphere perfectly. Ori wouldn't be Ori without the music. 

Like the first, much of the fun comes from traversal of the environment. You'll unlock lots of abilities that will allow you to move around your environment with ease. What starts out as highly cumbersome to get through becomes a breeze. Though you'll backtrack a lot to get the items you missed the first time, it is genuinely a delight to get around the environment, especially once you unlock the final ability that makes all the hard to get places so much more fun to get to. Ori's got some hardcore parkour skills. 

This game is a massive improvement over Blind Forest, with the devs taking a hard look at many of the things that made the first a bit of a chore on occasion and fleshing them out to the point of approaching perfection. The game is short, though a fair bit longer than the first - getting all items and unlockables takes around 15 hours. Despite this, the game ends right on time where the various mechanics would otherwise start to get really boring without some really intense changes. 


All in all, I cannot recommend this game enough. It's very close to being a masterpiece. Flaws and all, there is nothing in this game that is not worth the time and enjoyment.

139413281.review:
9-10/10 Game. Easily.

The Soundtrack is phenomenal. I never get annoyed of hearing it. Will likely listen to the soundtrack while I work.
The world is beautiful. The art style no different than the first game, but wildly expanded upon.
The combat is... well its intentionally a little lackluster here and there. More on that below.
The movement is super nice. It feels really good and crisp. You have so many ways to traverse and I love it.
The story compelling if you're willing to listen. Even then, it's pretty visual so it's hard to miss whats going on unless you skip the cutscenes. I almost teared up at the end.

On combat:
The Ori Franchise is part of the metroidvania genre, but it takes a scenic route approach. It's beautiful and easy. Even when made hard, it's significantly easier than other games. Because of this, the combat is not as moment to moment intense and sharp. If you're expecting fluid and amazing combat from Hollow Knight, you will most definitely not get it here. It is however smooth. The movement is great and makes up for the lacking combat. Befitting of the story and atmosphere, you don't have to fight everything, you can smoothly move (schmove) around them. And it feels really good.

I adore this game and look forward for more from this developer.

The most beautiful game I've ever played and probably will ever play. I prefer the visuals to the first game, and in many cases the more 3D looking characters look better. The gameplay is great, I love Metroidvanias, especially ones with good movement and abilities, which Ori games excel at, as well as a lot to do, find and defeat. The spirit shard system is good too, even though I normally end up using the same ones. The bosses are fun and challenging and so are the escape sequences. I also really like how partway through the game you have four areas to go to at the same time, non-linearity is great imo. The music is incredible as well.

The only thing that could've been better is the map layout. It's a bit too flat for my liking, I prefer in Hollow Knight where you can take a bunch of different routes to get places because it's such a square shaped map. 138719186.review:
Ori Will of the Wisps is a light narrative driven Metrovanian platformer. You play as Ori, a spirit of the forest and start out trying to rescue one of your friends. You meet a variety of denizens of the forest while learning new combat and travel abilities. This is the sequel to Ori and the Blind Forest.

Gameplay - 4/5. The platforming is good, but I'm docking a point for some of the sand burrowing as tight turns I found incredibly difficult to pull off with the controls. If you like fast paced platforming, this game is for you. Normal adventure have you hopping from place to place, unlocking secrets and removing obstacles to get further and further, all while gathering new abilities and resources. Boss battles are a combination of avoidance where you have a 'run the gauntlet' type of chase either from the boss or from a natural disaster (or both) and then another part where you are battling the bosses with your combat abilities. 
Graphics - I've found Ori's art style to be enchanting and the designers are able to tell a story and make you feel emotions with just the graphics and the creatures that inhabit the world. While this isn't a graphically intense game for your rig, I enjoyed all the spectacle. 5/5.
Music - haunting light melodies run throughout the game offset by oppressive chase music when called for. they're appropriate for the situations and pleasant on the ears but I didn't find any of them sticking out to me and eventually listened to iTunes instead. 3/5.
Story - This is a very light 'story' to the game but what they do deliver did have me get emotional and root for the characters. My only issue with the story was the very ending, [spoiler] with one character, the main boss, really having a disservice in its ending. They gave the boss' backstory and then just left them in their poor existence. I would have liked some redemption and acceptance after the life they lived, but I just like happy endings. [/spoiler] A 4/5 from me.
Fun factor - I did find a few frustrations in the game, there were a few points that the solution to opening the next area eluded me and I had to look up the solutions but I'm not the best at puzzles. The actual gameplay is fun and I enjoyed the game but won't be replaying it any time soon. 4/5.
overall - a delightful and charming experience. I highly recommend! 4/5.

Great metroidvania that really leans into the physics of propelling yourself around.

The most enjoyable parts of the game were the chase scenes, which were full-engagement run & react nail biters.

For me, the least enjoyable were the actual race challenges, because without the drama of the chase, the repeated attempts to perfectly execute the skills/movements became repetitive and frustrating. But then you finally get it and feel amazing sense of accomplishment. I only retried a race once and /shudder/.

The combat with the minor mobs was generally pretty fun, and the environmental gameplay was interestingly challenging (pre- and post-"the getting of the skill that makes this part easy").

When the combat was physics-intensive, especially the very last battle, it really shines, but is unforgiving.

I loved this game!

138580106.review:
Beautiful game, great soundtrack, and strong story. Fun game to play, but I ran into issues with lag and screen tearing the more I played and I don't know why. I don't believe it is actually my computer as I have not experienced this before on other games and have seen others say they suffer similarly. It made for a frustrating experience in those situations.

Otherwise I've seen this game compared to Hollow Knight and while they are very similar on the surface I would not say if you loved one you'll love the other. HK is a one difficulty game that is filled to the brim with varying bosses you learn to overcome with some complicated platforming while Ori is really giving you a great and beautiful looking story with some bosses. The platforming is more extreme in Ori, but the way the game is set up is not anywhere near as punishing as HK is. Granted you can play Ori at a higher difficulty to get a true souls-like experience, but just playing through on Normal is nothing excessively difficult.

Both are great games in their own right; if you want a very difficult and unforgiving game that forces you to adapt or die play HK; if you want a game that is pretty with a straightforward story and a stellar soundtrack play Ori, and kick up the difficulty if you are into that.

138446358.review:
I remember buying this game for my sister a few years back. Didn't think much of it at the time, but I thought it would be a nice gift for her. I remember seeing her playing it from time to time, the message indicating that she'd started playing it popping up on the corner of my screen. There was always a certain small pride in seeing that, because to me it meant that she was enjoying my gift.
Last September she committed suicide.

After everything had more or less settled down from that, I sat down and booted up her computer. All that was on there was Chrome, Steam, Word, and a few games. One of them, of course, was Core keeper.
She had played this game to pieces, clocking over 170 hours and owning practically everything the game had to offer. She had used every square inch to its maximum potential, and was making ridiculous amounts of loot. It was only then did I see just how much she loved my present. No other game she played quite captured her affection as much as this one. None of her friends really knew about it, however; it seems like she preferred to keep it to herself. Like it was her own little bit of heaven she could turn to whenever she wanted.

And because of that, I can't help but smile whenever I play this game.

I cannot recommend it enough; every bit of hard work the developer put into this masterpiece shows in every single aspect. The music is catchy and memorable (I'll often find myself humming certain tunes from it), the world feels lived-in and natural, and the gameplay is incredibly laid back and enjoyable. It's hard to stop once I get invested in the game; minutes can easily turn into several hours. And now, with the multiplayer beta, I play for even longer with my friends, each of us dedicated to our desired jobs. Most of all, however, we're all just happy to be together.

En primer lugar, según la altura de un minion (que es de 3.5 pies en promedio) gru tiene 4 minions de alto, lo que significa que tiene un tamaño divino de 14 pies de alto (4.27 metros). En segundo lugar, si alguno de ustedes recuerda en la primera de mi villano favorito, sabrían que hay una escena en la que vector secuestra a las 3 chicas y dispara una serié de misiles en busca de calor a gru y los esquiva todos. Según la velocidad de un misil balístico promedio (3060 km /h) y el tamaño del misil según el tamaño de su tobillo, gru puede percibir y moverse a una velocidad tal que los misiles parecen moverse solo a 15 km /h. Por último, cuando gru golpea mas tarde a un tiburón, lo paraliza. Esto significa que probablemente le rompió la columna vertebral. Se requería una fuerza de 3000 newtons para fracturar la columna, que es igual al impacto creado por un automóvil de 230 kg que se estrella contra una pared a 50 km /h. Gru puede levantar la luna, que tiene una masa de 7.34767309 x 1022 kilogramos (1.61988463 x 1023 libras). Cuando esta en la tierra, lo sostiene con una mano y evita cualquier tipo de interferencia gravitacional. A partir de esto, esta claro que gru puede manipular las partículas fundamentales del universo, gravitones en este caso. Sin mencionar que construyó un mini-cohete completamente funcional con chatarra cuando era niño (ni siquiera un adolecente). Para alcanzar la velocidad de escape de la tierra, su cohete debe haber sido capaz de viajar a mas de 11.2 km /s (25,000 mph), lo que significa que comprimió la tecnología de la NASA en el tamaño de una silla.El coeficiente intelectual promedio de un científico de cohetes es de aproximadamente 130 o más, y para que gru construya un cohete del tamaño de una silla a, digamos, 10 años, debe tener un coeficiente intelectual muy superior a 130.No es irracional decir que podría estar en el rango de mas de 200.

138283116.review:
[h1][b]Ori and the Will of the Wisps[/b][/h1]

[b]Ori and the Will of the Wisps is one of the greatest platformers of all time![/b]

There are no shortage of fantastic 2D metroidvania platformers on Steam, such as Hollow Knight, Shovel Knight, Dead Cells, Guacamelee and The Messenger and despite this great pantheon of champions, I would dare say that Ori and the Will of the Wisps belongs at the very top! 

It is the only game out of all the aformentioned games that I have 100%'ed. It is a drastic improvement from the first game (Ori and the Blind Forrest) and improves on literally every single aspect, except for the music, which is just as good in the first game. The music in this game is astounding and you owe it to yourself and to Gareth Coker to purchase the soundtrack! The gameplay is wildly improved. I was not a big fan of the combat in the first game, and thankfully it has been completely overhauled, with a greater variety of abilities that all feel truly transformative and impactful, along with shards you can equip to boost your abilities even further. They have also made it so you can heal by holding down "B" if you're on controller, much like Hollow Knight which is a great feature that I am happy is in this game! Boss fights are exhilarating and intense, with once again, an incredible musical accompaniment by Gareth Coker. 

Visually the game is sharper, more colorful, more fluent in animation and just a resplendent treat for the eyes all the way through. With a big map to explore, there is plenty of beauty to be found. Speaking of beauty, the story is surprisingly powerful and sweet, with a great ending and tradeoff, and with a beautiful and heartwrenching musical score by Gareth Coker! (Yes, I am mentioning his name ad libitum in this review, because the man's name deserves to be spoken for his incredbible work!). 

[h1][b]Final Verdict 10/10[/b][/h1]

[b]The game borrows ideas from other great games of the same genre, and despite this, Ori holds its own identity and heart just as those that came before it. It is the pinacle of 2D metroidvania platformers right now, with every aspect being done meticulously and passionately! Well polished and an unforgetable time guaranteed![/b]

138278125.review:
I wanted to write this to talk about the ending since I think the rest of the game is talked about enough. Even though other aspects of the game are good I will not play it again.

[spoiler] So basically, Moon had no plans for a sequel. This is obvious because Blind Forest was a complete story. Microsoft wanted another game and Hollow Knight was popular so they copied it. As for the story, they copied it from the first game and added some things here and there. This story is the product of crunch and different writers working on it. 

The ending is the scrapped ending which was intended for BF (where it would have worked better). Here it feels unnecessary, forced and rushed. We are told that Ori should stay and become a guardian of this forest, but we assume that she will be mobile like the other guardians, and also she has already accomplished a lot in that state. But no, Ori has no choice but to die by fusing with the light that we met five minutes ago even though there was no immediate danger like fire and even though Niwen was doing fine for the most part. (again these factors were different in Blind Forest and that's why the ending would have worked better there). I do not consider this game canon.

This is also an attempt to kill off the main character so the devs don't have to do another game (they said themselves "we can't make Ori games forever). Moon may have succeeded on this (and dividing the community), they will not do another Ori game but Microsoft could still do it, although I have no expectations. [/spoiler]

138142214.review:
A more than just worthy sequel to the first game!

As I stated in my review to "Ori and the Blind Forest", the game roughly resembles "Hollow Knight" while being way easier. The sequel, "Ori and the Will of the Wisps", has even more similarities to the "Hollow Knight" - the way one unlocks abilities, the way one can buy maps for different locations, etc. And yet, it's less challenging while still being not too easy - which, in my case, is a huge plus.

The story is nice and touching, the graphics are beautiful, and the whole feeling of exploring the vast world and fighting off enemies keeps one engaged till the end. Different zones require different mechanics to pass, some parts are quite frustrating the first time around, but in the end everything is manageable. Even the few boss fights hardly require more than a few tries - again, a huge plus for someone who isn't a masochistic Dark Souls fan.

All in all, a wonderful experience, arguably even better than the first part - in my very humble opinion, that is.

138069288.review:
After playing the first game, I had high expectations for this game, and it smashed my expectations. Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a sequel that changes the game completely. Real quickly, with out getting to much into spoilers, here is a quick change/add list. 

[spoiler]
- A lot more weapons, which feel unique and varied
-Side Quest
-Talk able NPCs
-Combat Gauntlets
-Builds that you can customize your play style
-Bosses and Minibosses
[/spoiler]

Here are the Pros and Cons of the game 

[h1] Pros [/h1]

Music - Just as the first game, the music is fantastic, always masterfully made to fit the current environment. 

Combat - Combat was one of the biggest negatives from the first game, but now it is one of the biggest positives. There is no way to express it in words, it feels so fluid, and feels amazing

Enemy Types- There are now a lot more enemies to fight, which is a good thing when the combat feels good. If the previous game had around 7 types of enemies. This game has around 15, which is a big improvement. 

The World - Just as the first game, the new world is great. Each place feel even more varied, and has its unique twist to it. 

Bosses - The Bosses in the game are all very good. Some times, when you are fighting, its feels like an anime, the way you are dashing around. 

Story - A simple yet effective story that can make a grown man cry

[h1] Cons [/h1]

Certain Side Quests - There are some side quests, that are pretty boring. Whether its just a fetch quest to an NPC, or  grabbing an item for an NPC

Health/Energy System - To be clear, the health and mana [b] BARS [/b] themselves have not changed, just the way that you use them. 
        -To gain back your health, you are given a ability very early in the game, that gives you 3 health per 1 cell of energy use, which is very overpowered. In my opinion that caused me to not be careful because I can always just heal myself so quickly.  

        -To Get More maxed Health/Energy, its the same, however, instead of in the first game, if you only need one collectible to increase the respective bar, you need to find two items, because they are in halves this time. Not the biggest thing in the world but just a pet peeve. 

[h1] Ending Thoughts [/h1]

This game in my opinion is a lot better for the first game. If you liked the first game, or consider buying the games, I would highly recommend it. 

9/10

138053917.review:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a breathtakingly beautiful game that will take you on an emotional journey through a stunningly crafted world. You play as Ori, a small forest spirit on a quest to save their family and friends.

As you navigate through the lush environments, you'll encounter challenging obstacles and epic boss battles. But fear not, Ori has a range of abilities at their disposal, from double jumps to spirit blasts, to help you on your quest.

What really sets Ori and the Will of the Wisps apart is its heartwarming story and unforgettable characters. You'll meet a cast of creatures, each with their own unique personality, and follow their struggles and triumphs.

And let's not forget about the game's stunning art and music, which work together to create a truly immersive experience.

All in all, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a game that will leave you feeling inspired and moved. It's a must-play for anyone who loves beautiful art, captivating stories, and challenging gameplay.

Graphics: Gorgeous, incredible drawing and visualization
Location design: All location are unique
Plot: It looks simple, but it doesn't get worse for a moment, it can make you worry and maybe even cry 
Gameplay: Much better, there are old and new mechanics and that's awesome. I guess the idea for map and amulets was taken from another great game (Hollow Knight) and it suits well
Music: A masterpiece, every stage you pass is accompanied by music, battles and escapes - heroic music, each location contains its own soothing mood, sad moments from the plot mixed with music, give a storm of emotions

The game demonstrates that evil is not born, but comes at the moment when someone tries to do justice due to a loss, as a result of which everyone suffers. Also it shows that: you can't always help everyone, there won't always be a happy ending, and concessions can always change everything. PS: Poor Shriek, she doesn't deserve her fate..
The game is unsurpassed, so I advise you to try it and get into it with your heart.

138045346.review:
"Ori and the Will of the Wisps" is an absolutely stunning masterpiece of a game that takes you on an emotional journey that will leave you feeling awed and moved. From the moment I started playing, I was completely swept away by the beauty and wonder of the game's art and music.
The story of Ori and his quest to save his loved ones is both heart-wrenching and inspiring. The game takes you on a rollercoaster ride of emotions, from joy and wonder to heartache and sadness.
But despite the emotional weight of the story, the game is also incredibly fun to play. While many platformer games rely solely on combat, making the game hard by throwing overpowered bosses, Ori games has always focused on the movement mechanics being challenging as well while also not being completely unfair. And the game's many side-quests, hidden areas, spirit trials, etc. kept me exploring every nook and cranny of the world well past the actual story. 
But what really sets "Ori and the Will of the Wisps" apart is the way it makes you feel. The game's themes of love, loss, and perseverance are woven into every aspect of the game, its "painting coming to life" like visuals and gorgeous music, to the characters and their struggles.
Overall, a truly remarkable game that touched me in ways that few games ever have. It is a testament to the power of video games to tell deeply emotional and impactful stories, and it is an experience that I will never forget. If you're a fan of platformers, or just looking for a game that will move you to tears, I cannot recommend it highly enough.

137661797.review:
I have both Ori games in my library but haven't actually played the first one. This game was alright but I think I have had my fill in the 14 or so hours I actually played this for and I have no desire to play the first one right now. The story is not good and will not make you cry despite what you might have heard. It is very shallow and takes itself way too seriously. Unlike Hollow Knight, the world lacks depth and cohesion and feels designed solely for the player to mess around in. The game is beautiful but the visuals are so overwhelming and Ori is so tiny sometimes you cannot see your character and they die. I died during an escape sequence and a boss fight because the particle effects and cinematic camera turned my character into a literal dot - a white dot on a snowy incline. 

The core gameplay is pretty fun. The combat with the sword is satisfying but the combat abilities are all pretty useless. Why set an enemy on fire when just spamming attack with the sword does the trick? Even the combat shrines where you do combat trials for ability slots never has more than 4 enemies on screen. Ori's sword can easily stagger every enemy except the ones with shields who make you switch to your hammer for 3 seconds. The bow does no damage and fire, shuriken etc are just not as satisfying as the basic sword. All these abilities feel like they were added in because a committee forced the developers to.

 Ori is not a challenging or frustrating game. The game autosaves every minute and so there is no tension at all. You literally cannot lose progress but you might die a lot during some of the platforming sections because the controls and Ori are both very floaty. 

The Moki are adorable though. Easily the most likeable characters in the game. A lot of the side quests are engaging and well thought out and I actually wanted to complete them, which is rare. Overall, this is a solid 7/10.

I bought this for less than 2 dollars, If you buy this for 2 dollars, it is definitely worth it but for anything higher than a fiver, no.

137588657.review:
Normally I don't review many games, especially not this much but this is the best game I've played in my entire life. It's adding brand new mechanics every 20 minutes that are easy to learn and make the game feel amazing. I've been playing a lot of platformers recently and none of them have been as perfect as this one. It could be a little longer but there's so many collectibles it doesn't matter. I'm not kidding when I say this is the perfect game. I won't have as many hours in it as some of my others because it isn't very long but I'll 100% it which I don't do for most games and it has good replayability. I really don't think I'll play a game better than it for a long while. I got it on sale for $6 but it's worth the $30. I try to only buy games that will have long play times but this game is so good that you don't need that. I played the blind forest and it was good but wow, this is perfect.

137528670.review:
Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a stunningly beautiful and emotionally charged 2D platformer game developed by Moon Studios. It follows the story of Ori, a small and nimble spirit guardian, as they embark on a quest to save their forest home from a looming threat.

One of the game's standout features is its breathtaking visuals and art design, which create a vibrant and immersive world that is both beautiful and dangerous. The game's environments are richly detailed and full of life, with a range of creatures and characters to meet and interact with.

The game's platforming mechanics are also exceptional, with precise controls and a range of skills and abilities to master. Ori can jump, glide, and dash through the world with grace and agility, making for a satisfying and engaging gameplay experience.

The game's story is emotionally charged and deeply moving, with a range of memorable characters and moments that will stick with players long after they finish the game. The game's themes of friendship, loss, and redemption are expertly woven into the narrative, creating a story that is both engaging and impactful.

The game's soundtrack is also exceptional, with a range of beautifully crafted pieces that perfectly match the game's visuals and themes. Every sound in the game is expertly crafted to create an immersive and engaging experience that draws players into the world of Ori and the Will of the Wisps.

Overall, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a masterpiece of game design that offers a rich and engaging platforming experience with stunning visuals, an emotional story, and exceptional sound design. Whether you're a fan of platformers, adventure games, or just looking for a unique and immersive gaming experience, Ori and the Will of the Wisps is a game that is definitely worth playing.

151403072.review: Alright, I know I said it for Blind Forest, but this is the absolute best game I have played in my life. From the stellar animation to the calming music and smooth as butter gameplay, this masterpiece is incredible. After playing this, the previous game is near impossible to return to. Everything was improved so, so much, especially the movement. The level design is also substantially better, that with being a more interconnected world. Also, I especially love the fact that, rather than just restoring the land in the previous game, you also restore the life it once held. This is one of the few games I have played that calmed me down this much. The combat has also been majorly improved, with significantly more diversity in how you can defeat your enemies. However, there is one singular issue, and that is some of the controls. Occasionally, in the final "dungeon" of the game, a specific power for floating wouldn't work half of the time. Anyways, that aside, this game is easily a 10/10, and I can't wait to see what Moon Studios makes next! keep up the great work!
